Circumstances are expressions indicating prevailing physical conditions or states of affairs concurrent  to the breathing event.  'They respire at lower levels of light, temperature, and tissue moisture than bryophytes.'
An action that the Agent intends to accomplish by breathing in the specified manner.  'Blanche respired steadily to allow the tension to subside.'

Escaping.definition: A Self-moving Escapee departs from an Undesirable_location.   'Benjamin escaped from Germany.'

arguments.definition: The Escapee manages to leave the Undesirable_location. 'Benjamin escaped from Germany.'
Goal identifies any expression which tells where the Escapee ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.  'Benjamin escaped to the United States.'
covers any act performed by the Escapee brings about the escape.   'Benjamin escaped from Germany by bribing the border guards.'

Manner is used for any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion, including descriptions of steadiness, grace, means of motion, etc.  'Benjamin escaped from Germany with difficulty.'
The Undesirable_location is where the Escapee begins.  'Benjamin escaped  from Germany.'
Speed idenitifies the rate at which the escaping occurs.  'Benjmain speedily escaped  from Germany.'
Vehicle identifies the means of conveyance by which the Escapee leaves the Undesirable_location.  'Benjamin escaped in a lorrie.'
This FE identifies the Time when the escaping occurs.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the escaping takes place. 'Benjamin escaped from Germany to rsave his life.'
This FE identifies the Place where the Escaping occurs.
Depictive identifies a word or  phrase describing a participant of an action. 'Benjamin escaped unscathed.'
Path describes the trajectory of motion of the Escapee.  'Benjmain escaped from Germany along the southern border.'
This FE identifies the (abstract) nearness of the Escapee to being caught in the Undesirable_location.  'Benjamin's narrow escape from Germany left him fearful.'
The distance along a path away from the Undesirable_location that the Escapee travels.  'She escaped a few feet away, then looked back at him coldly.'
The situation that explains why the (instance of) the event occurred.  'We flew the coop 'cuz we knew pappy was coming home .'

Avoiding.definition: An Agent avoids an Undesirable_situation under certain Circumstances. That situation may be an activity (e.g. going to school), or an entity (perhaps) metonymic for such an activity or situation (e.g. the curb).  In this frame, the situation is undesirable from the Agent's point of view (e.g. evade), and contrasts with scenes in which the situation is specifically undesirable to someone else (e.g. forbear) or from the point of view of an external morality (e.g. abstain).  'Mike avoided his supervisor at all costs.'

arguments.definition: The Agent avoids an Undesirable_situation. 'Mike avoided his supervisor at all costs.'
This FE identifies the Place where the avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the Time when the avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the Purpose avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the situation that the Agent avoids. 'Mike avoided his supervisor at all costs.'
This FE identifies the Means by which avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the Manner in which avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the Circumstances under which the Undesirable_situation is avoided. 'Mike avoided his supervisor at all costs.'
This FE identifies the Degree to which avoiding occurs.
This FE identifies the Explanation for which avoiding occurs.

Evading.definition: An Evader moves under its own power to thereby avoid Capture  or contact with a Pursuer, also generally moving under its own power. This frame characterizes a  more specific event  than Avoiding in that both the Evader and the Pursuer are moving entities.  In addition, this frame differs from Escaping by requiring a Pursuer and being neutral about the prior captivity of the Evader.  'I gave my handler the slip.'  'He evaded capture for several hours.'

arguments.definition: This FE is used for phrases that describe a general Area in which motion occurs when it is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.  'Smithers fled and evaded them all over the ship.'</def-root >
Path is used for any description of a trajectory of the motion of the Evader, including directional phrases.  'Smithers fled northward.'  'Smithers evaded the police through the empty field.'

The Evader moves under its own power to Capture or contact with the Pursuer. Normally the Evader frame element is expressed as an external argument.   'The mouse eluded the cats for only a few minutes.'

This  FE identifies  the Mode_of_transportation that the Evader uses to move.  It can either bea part of the Evader's own body or a vehicle. ' Smithers got away from us on foot .' ' Smithers got away from us on bike .'
This FE identifies the Means by which the Evader bringd about the evasion.   'Smithers evaded the police by ducking behind the dumpster.'
The Pursuer is going after the Evader unless they act.  'The mouse eluded the cats for only a few minutes.'
This FE is used for any expression that describes  the Degree to which the Evader avoids Capture or contact with the Pursuer.  'The mouse barely eluded the cats.'

This FE identifies the Manner in which the evading occurs.  It is used for any expression that does not relate directly to the trajectory of motion, including speed, steadiness, and grace. 'Smithers evaded the police gracefully.'
This  FE identifies the Purpose for which the Evading is done.  'Smithers evaded the police to prevent being captured.'
This FE identifies the Explanation for which the Evading is. done. 'Smithers fled because he feared capture.'
This FE identifies the Circumstances under which the Evader evades the Pursuer, or avoids Capture.  'Smithers evaded the police at all costs.'
This FE identifies the Time at which the Evading occurs. 'Smithers got away at the stroke of midnight.'
Depictive is used to identify the state of any of the participants in the evading event.  'Smithers evaded the police barefoot.'
This FE marks the Speed at which the Evader evades the Pursuer. 'Smithers got away from the police at lightning speed.'
An actual or hypothetical  event in which the Pursuer takes physical control of the Evader.  'Rmirez-Snchez , tried in absentia , had evaded capture since the murders in Paris on June 27 , 1975 '

Cause_to_move_in_place.definition: An Agent causes a Theme to move with respect to a certain Fixed_location, generally with a certain Periodicity, without undergoing unbounded translational motion or significant alteration of configuration/shape. 'Paul shook the remote control frantically.'

arguments.definition: Theme identifies the object involved in motion.
This FE  identifies the Place where the event occurs.
The amount of time for which a state holds or a process is ongoing.
This FE identifies the Explanation for which an event occurs.
This FE identifies the Time when the event occurs.
Manner of performing an action
The Means is the way in which the motion in place is instigated.
Degree to which event occurs
The number of times the Theme returns to a state in a given duration. 'It turns at 1000 rpms.'

The point or set of points that define the limits of motion for the Theme.  For spinning motions, it is the axis, for vibrating it is a boundary, for swinging it is a point. 'She twirled around him several times.' 'Balls spin on their axes .' 'The window vibrated in the frame.' 'He swung by a single handhold.'
The Agent performs the intentional act.
This FE identifies the Instrument with which an intentional act is performed.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which an intentional act is performed.
Angle identifies the amount that the Theme turns. 'Spin the dial a quarter turn.'
The Agent's manipulation of an Theme may be further specified as being localized to some part of the Theme, a Locus.  This FE is usually expressed as a PP Complement.  'Pat squeezed Jo by the hand.'
This FE identifies the part of the Agent's body being used to manipulate the Theme.   'Kim twirled the glass in his fingers.'
Cause identifies the non-agentive force that causes the motion in place. 'The wind vibrated the string.'
This frame element is used for all path-like expressions, that express the Direction of the swinging, vibrating or rotating.
This FE identifies the Result of an event.

Food.definition: This frame contains words referring to items of food.  'Specialties include deep fried shredded beef , duck , prawn dishes and hand-made noodles.'

arguments.definition: This FE indicates a characteristic or description of the food.  ' She drinks low-fat milk'
This FE identifies a particular Type of the food item. ' cooking apple' 'Granny Smith apple.'
A part of the Food.  'You'd be surprised, but it was hard to eat a banana with such a thick peel.'

Text_creation.definition: An Author creates a Text, either written, such as a letter, or spoken, such as a speech,  that contains meaningful linguistic tokens, and may have a particular Addressee in mind.  The Text may include information about its topic, although the latter is not an FE in this frame.  'I penned a letter concerning racism  to Congress.' 'The brothers said not two words to each other.' 'Jot any notes you need below the line in red pen only.'

arguments.definition: The Author produces a particular Text.
The Components are the parts that the Author uses to construct the Text. ' Caitlin wrote the book from memoirs she collected.'
The entity which results from the act of writing or speaking. 'Michael wrote a frame description.' ' Cybil wanted to speak those three words.'
Depictive phrase describing the actor of an action 'I wrote everything in that decade on drugs.'
The instrument with which an intentional act is performed.
Where the event takes place.
Manner of performing an action.  This frame includes some peculiar examples of manner phrases. Write it in pen.   Write it in ink.
This FE identifies the Means by which a Text is created.
The purpose for which an intentional act is performed.
This FE identifies the Time at which the text is created.

This is the person to whom the Message is communicated. When this FE is expressed, it often appears in a prepositional phrase introduced by to, or as the direct object, or as the first object in a double object construction.
Beneficiary identifies the person in whose honor or for whose benefit the Text is created.
This FE describes the form in which the text is presented.  'Yeats wrote out his poems in prose.'
The Explanation for creating the text. 'I wrote the article because I would have lost my teaching post otherwise.'
The language in which the Text is represented or the physical materials upon which the Text is recorded.  'I wrote the code on the back of the envelope.'

Reading_perception.definition: The Reader attends to a Text to process its information.  Sometimes a particular kind of Sought_phenomenon is sought in the Text. '' The metaphor which allows motion verbs plus "through" to express reading (e.g. "went through the text", "slogging through the phonebook", "sped through the dialogue passages") is considered to be productive, and thus should be annotated in the Motion frames.  The metaphor applies most productively to motion verbs that do not specify motor program and either specify no manner information at all (e.g. "go") or only specify the manner of motion in terms of difficulty and/or speed ("slog", "speed"), although other verbs with specific information ("saunter", "swim") may occur in more colorful usage.  'I read A Tale of Two Cities last night.'

arguments.definition: The one who examines a Text to understand it.
The entity that contains linguistic symbols.
Degree to which event occurs
A particular characteristic or thing that the Reader intends to process. Read Chapter 7 only for the major concepts..
Manner of performing an action
An act that allows the Reader to read in the specified manner. 'I skimmed the book by reading just the section headings and the first sentences after.'
The Purpose is the reason for which the Reader reads the Text.
When the reading event takes place. 'Charlie often reads the newspaper at night.'
Where the reading event takes place. 'Surprisingly, few of the students read much at all in the designated reading rooms.'
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
The context wherein the Reader reads a particular Text.

Intentionally_create.definition: The Creator creates a new entity, the Created_entity, possibly out of Components.  'The Libyans were generating arms for export.'

arguments.definition: The Creator creates a created entity.
This FE identifies the place ehere the Agent intentionally creates the new entity.
This FE identifes the Time when an Agent intentionally creates a new entity.
This FE identifies the purpose for which an Agent intentionally creates a new entity.
This FE identifies the Components that are attached together to form a Created_entity. 'He made a jungle gym out of iron bars.'
This FE identifies a depictive phrase describing the actor or undergoer of an action.
This FE identifies the entity that the Agent intentionally creates. 'They were generating grenades for export.'

Any description of the creation event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of a Creator that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
This FE identifies the Means by which a Creator intentionally creates a new entity.
This FE identifies the instrument with which an Agent intentionally creates a Created_entitiy.
The role of Created_entity.  'This particular book was created as an introductory text.'
A secondary agent with whom the Creator intentionally creates the Created_entity.  'Emily set up the business with the former president of Intersoft, Inc.'

Giving_birth.definition: A Mother and Father produce a Child or an Egg. 'Betty bore Gerry three intelligent daughters.'

arguments.definition: Mother is the female creature that produces the Child. 'Betty bore Gerry three intelligent daughters.'
Child identifies the new self-motile creature produced from the Mother and Father. 'Betty bore Gerry three intelligent daughters.'
Father is the male creature that copulates with the Mother, thus  leading to the birth of the Child.  'Betty bore Gerry three intelligent daughters.'
This FE identifies the Place where the event occurs.
This FE identifies the Time when the event occurs.
Depictive identifies the phrase describing a participant of an action  ' Demons are spawned fully formed.'
This FE identifies the Circumstances under which a Mother and Father produce produce a Child.  'Star fish can be spawned under the right conditions.'
Egg is an immobile object containing an organism that may hatch as a mobile, infant organism.  'Female clownfish lay their eggs around sea anemones'
This FE identifies the Means by which the event occurs.
The Mother and Father expressed together. 'We are going to be having twins!'
This FE identifies the Result of  the birth. 'John's mother bore him into a wealthy family.'

Any description of the intentional act which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of the Parents (or a Father or Mother) that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).   'They eagerly spawned more of their kind until there was no room for more.'

Being_employed.definition: An Employee has a Position doing work in a particular Field, or doing work on a particular Task, for which an Employer gives Compensation to the Employee.  ' Undocumented foreigners are working as  building contractors for Laing Builders.'

arguments.definition: The Compensation is the payment that the Employee receives for performing a Task.  'Louise works as an engineer for $1,000'
The Employee is obligated to perform a Task in order to receive Compensation.  'My Mom works for the Michigan Department of Agriculture.'
The Employer gives Compensation to an Employee.  'My mom works for an Eye Doctor.'

This FE identifies the Manner in which an Employee works for an Employer.  ' Last weekend, the commercial TV station Nova broadcast testimonies of young Czechs who have worked illegally for America's largest retailer, Wal-Mart.'
This FE identifies the Place_of_employment of the Employee.  'The undocumented foreigners were working at the organic farm.'
The label given to a particular type of employment.   'Louise works as an engineer.'
This FE identifies the Purpose for which an Employee  is in employment.  'He waited tables to finance his education at St. Lawrence University, where he was a top-notch wrestler.'
The Employee is obligated to perform the Task to recieve Compensation from the Employer .  'My dad works building houses.'

This FE identifies the Time period during which an Employee  works for an Employer.  'From 2000-2001, Mr. Eckhardt clerked for The Honorable Jerry A. Funk, United States Bankruptcy Judge, Middle District of Florida.'
This FE identifies the Field in which one works.  'Undocumented foreigners work in construction for years.'
This FE identifies the amount of Time for which the Employee continues being employed.  'She worked for 10 years in private and hospital practice and 19 years in teaching and administration.'
Rank is the position in a hierarchy that an Employee occupies within the organization of the Employer.   'Sue has the  top job in the company.'
This FE identifies the Type of the profession.  'He's harkening back to a time before Bush became president and he had a white collar job and wore a suit.'

The Contract_basis describes the conditions of employment with respect to permanency, hours per time period, or payment basis.  'As much as possible, however, do not attempt to run a full-time business in addition to holding a full-time job .'
The location where the Employee works.  'Most people work in the city.'
How often the Employee works.
This FE gives a description of the Being_employed event.
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.

Setting_fire.definition: This frame describes either the creation of a Flame by a Kindler or non-sentient Cause, or the igniting of Flammables by a Kindler or a Cause.  'Taliban militants recently set fire to several schools.'  'The fire ignited. CNI'

arguments.definition: The Kindler is the person performing the intentional act. ' Mark started the fire with a magnifying glass. '
The Flame is what is created by the Kindler. 'Oscar started the fire.'
The Flamables is the the object that is set on fire by the Kindler. 'Tracy set the couch on fire.'
The cause of the fire. 'A spark ignited the curtains.'
This FE identifies the Time when the event occurs.
This FE identifies the Place where the event takes place.

Any description of the intentional act which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of a Kindler that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
An event brought about by the Cause or the Kindler that actually makes the Flammables catch fire.
The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows.

This FE denotes an event that occurs or state of affairs that holds at a time that includes the time during which the event or state of affairs reported by the target occurs and of which it is taken to be a part.
This FE describes the Kindler as being in some state during the action.

Mass_motion.definition: A Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a Source to a Goal with some Path.   'Emails from so-called Nigerian princes flooded inboxes all over the US.'

arguments.definition: The mass of entities which moves.
Degree of abundance.
The place where the overall motion event takes place, thus including Source, Path, and Goal locations.  'Letters streamed in all over the country.'
When the event occurs.
The Speed is the rate at which motion occurs.
The Source is the location the Theme occupies initially before its change of location.   'Afterwards, the crowd flooded away from the ceremony. '
Path refers to (a part of the) ground the Mass_theme travels over or to a landmark the Mass_theme travels by.   'The door opened , and a crowd of people flooded past me, into the hall.'
Goal is the location the Mass_theme ends up in.    'Eager spectators crowded into the auditorium'
The amount of time for which a state holds or a process is ongoing.

This FE is any expression which characterizes the extent of motion.  This frame element occurs throughout the motion domain but is very infrequent in Motion.Noise. The engine 	spluttered forward a short way and stopped.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Mass_theme is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Mass_theme. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.  ' Fans poured in by boat and train.'

Any description of the motion event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of an Mass_theme that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully)  'Children crowded eagerly around us'
The spatial setting in which the Mass_motion takes place.  'In the main auditorium people crowded around Orange's newest computer'

This FE is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the Goal of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often Direction is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the Mass_theme, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
In cases wherein the Mass_theme is construed as a sentient entities, this FE denotes the state of affairs that the entities wish to bring about by mass movement.  'The ducks flocked south to mate.'

Silencing.definition: An Agent causes a Speaker to become silent, sometimes about a particular Topic.  'The teacher quieted the children's laughter.'

arguments.definition: The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
The instrument with which an intentional act is performed.
Where the event takes place.
The purpose for which an intentional act is performed. 'John quieted the crowd to reassert his authority.'
When the event occurs.
An act whereby the Agent silences the Speaker.
The sentient entity that is not communicating.
This is the subject matter to which the Message pertains. It is typically expressed as a PP Complement headed by about.
The Explanation for which an intentional act is performed. 'I hushed him because quiet hours were in effect.'
The Result is the final state of the Speaker.
The Expressor is the Speaker's voice or other communicative noise emitted by the Speaker. </def-root >

Any description of the silencing event  which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously) and general descriptions comparing events (the same way).   'Kim shushed Pat rather haughtily.'
The extent to which the Agent succeeds in creating silence.  'Valois silenced the crowd completely with one commanding gesture'

Contacting.definition: A Communicator (whose Location may be indicated) directs a Communication to an Addressee at a particular Address.  Note that no actual successful communicative act is implied, only the successful completion of acts which would establish the communication.  (In other words, Mari can e-mail Jon without Jon ever reading it.) NB:  The Address or Location_of_communicator may be a virtual address, such as an e-mail or telephone number.'Disgruntled voters phoned Congressman Neil at his Washington residence with complaints about the recent increases in corporate welfare.''She tried to call from the payphone down the street.'

arguments.definition: The person who uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a message to another person.'He  wrote to John.'
The physical or abstract setting in which the message is conveyed.'Opinions are usually called in over the telephone and are often given within 24 hours.'
The person that receives the message from the Communicator.'The company must be able to call  potential customers.'
This FE is used for a (metaphorical) place in a system of communication where Communicators and Addressees can access the system. 'You can telephone your senator at 555-5555.'

The information that the Communicator wishes to impart to the Addressee, often to get a particular response. In this frame the Communication is not necessarily received by the Addressee. 'Patients continually call in with questions.'

This FE identifies the Purpose for the Communicator contacting the Addressee. Often, this FE is used to identify a PP-for which indicates what the Communicator is attempting to obtain. 'Pat phoned to talk about the party.' 'For more information, call 1-EVANGELIST.'
This is the subject matter to which the message pertains. It is typically expressed as a PP Complement headed by "about". 'Call John about the party.'
The location occupied by the Communicator.'Does anyone e-mail the office from a phone booth?'
This FE identifies the place where the intentional act occurs.
This FE identifies the time when the Agent acts intentionally.
The Intermediary is the person who facilitates the contact. ' We contacted her  through her employer  .'
The Depictive notes the state of one of the participants in the contacting event.
The number of times a Communicator contacts the Addressee per unit of time.
Any description of the nature of the action (e.g. "the same way"), including especially internal states of the Communicator that also influence the way the action is carried out.
An action of the Communicator that enables them to make contact.

Prevarication.definition: A Speaker communicates about a Topic in such a way as to mislead an Addressee, either by telling outright lies or by presenting a message in a misleading form.  'I lied to you about your Christmas present.'

arguments.definition: The person who uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a deceptive Message to the Addressee. 'Politicians do nothing but tell lies about money.'
The person that receives a Message from the Speaker.  'You're kidding me!' 'Satan lies to everyone, including himself.'
Topic is the entity to which the proposition or propositions  relate, that they are about.  'You deceived me about the location of the diamonds.'
The location at which the deception occurs.
The time at which the deception occurs.
The (communicative) action performed by the Speaker in order to deceive the Addressee.
The length of Time that the Speaker spends on the Topic.
The goal of the Speaker's deceit of the Addressee
The extent to which the Speaker deceives the Addressee about the Topic.
This FE describes how often the Speaker discusses the Topic with the Addressee.

Cause_to_experience.definition: An Agent intentionally seeks to bring about an internal mental or emotional state in the Experiencer.  This frame in closely related to  Experiencer_obj.  ' Samantha terrorized the children into screaming. '

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent intentionally tries to bring about an internal mental or emotional state.
The Agent is an External Argument of the target word and purposefully arouses an emotional state.
The Experiencer is the person the Agent causes to have a particular emotional state.
This Frame Element is for expressions that elaborate the manner in which the Agent affects the Experiencer.
What the Agent intends to make the Experiencer do by causing a certain experience and the Experiencer actually does.
This FE identifies the Time when the Agent affects the Experiencer.
This FE identifies the Place where the Agent affects the Experiencer </def-root >
This FE identifies the Instrument with which the Agent brings about the emotional state.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which an Agent brings about the emotional state in the Experiencer.
Degree to which the Experiencer ends up feeling an emotion.  'He completely terrorized her.'

Shoot_projectiles.definition: An Agent causes a Firearm to discharge which induces the rapid motion of the Projectile.  'The bank robber shot at the clerks with an AK-47.' 'Shooting a cannonball isn't as easy as it looks.  CNI'  Note that usages with the Firearm as object are out of frame, belonging to Use_firearm.

arguments.definition: The device used by the Agent to cause the motion of the Projectile.
The entity whose rapid, dangerous motion is caused by the Agent and/or Firearm.
The Agent is the person performing the intentional act causing the motion of the Projectile.
This FE is any expression characterizing the extent of motion of the Theme. Pat threw the Javelin 50 meters.
This FE is the point at which the Theme ends up as a result of the motion. Kim threw the cat into the garden.
Manner of performing an action
An act of the Agent whereby the rapid motion of the Projectile is achieved.
This FE is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Source nor Goal. I pushed the trolley along the street.
This FE is the starting point of motion. Pat dragged the box out of the cupboard.
Degree to which event occurs
A description of the state of the Agent or Projectile during the event.  'He shot three arrows at the target, all unsuspecting as to why Harold had done so well.'

This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element. Kim pushed the lawnmower around the garden.
The location in which the shooting event takes place.  'The bankrobbers were crazy enough to shoot at the clerks with an AK-47 inside the bank'
The Time when the shooting event takes place.  'The robbers shot at the clerks as they ran out of the bank'
The Agent's purpose in launching the Projectile  'We mistook a satellite launched to study earthquakes to be a missile, so we shot it down over the Pacific.'

Use_firearm.definition: An Agent causes a Firearm to discharge, usually directing the projectile from the barrel of the Firearm (the Source), along a Path, and to a Goal. 'The Germans wouldn't stop shooting cannons at them.' 'Oswald fired twice through the window.'

arguments.definition: The self-directed entity that uses and activates the Firearm.
This FE identifies the Firearm that an Agent activates so that it rapidly propels a projectile.
This FE identifies the means by which an Agent uses the Firearm.
This FE identifies the manner in which an Agent uses the Firearm.
This FE identifies the place where the Agent intentionally affects the Patient.
This FE identifies the purpose for which an Agent uses the firearm. 'Firing cannons to have a good time is not my idea of prudence!'
This FE identifies the Time when the Agent fires the Firearm.
Goal is the location the Theme ends up in, or is intended to end up in. 'Who fired a pistol at my client?'
This is the path along which the projectiles travel.
The Source is the location of the Firearm from which projectiles originate.
Area is the setting in which the projectile's movement takes place.  'Sometimes they got together and fired off M-16 in the park.'
This FE identifies the number of times a firearm is used.
Depicitive phrase describing the state of a participant in the action.

Fall_asleep.definition: A Sleeper goes from wakefulness to an altered state of consciousness where they are largely unaware of their environment.  The LUs of this frame are differentiated by how quickly and deeply the state is entered and what causes the change (especially whether it comes about naturally as a result of sleepiness or is brought about by injury).  'I dozed off at about 1am.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Place where the event occurs.
The Sleeper is the entity that falls asleep.
This FE identifies the Time where the event occurs.

Cause_to_wake.definition: An Agent or Cause causes a Sleeper to transition from the Sleep_state to wakeful consciousness.  'The earthquake woke me from a nightmare.'

arguments.definition: Where the event takes place.
The person or being that is sleeping.
When the event occurs.
The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
This FE identifies the Instrument with which an Agent intentionally affects a Patient.
This FE identifies the Means by which an Agent intentionally affects a Patient.
This FE identifies the purpose for which an Agent wakes the Sleeper. 'John roused her to irritate her.'
This FE identifies the Explanation for which an intentional act is performed. Mary woke him because he looked troubled.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of Causes.  'The rain woke me.' 'The smell of cooking woke the children.'
This describes the state out of which the Sleeper is awakened.

Any description of the event (or state) which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously), force (hard, softly), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way).  It may also indicate salient characteristics of an Agent that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
The degree to which the Sleeper ends up awake.  'I couldn't manage to rouse him completely, he could only mumble.'

Sleep_wake_cycle.definition: A Sleeper enters a state of consciousness of reduced external awareness, remains in this state for some amount of time, and (normally) returns to full wakeful consciousness.

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Duration of time for which a state holds or a process is ongoing.
This FE identifies the Place where the event occurs.
The Sleeper is the entity that is sleeping.
This FE identifies the Time when the event occurs.

Waking_up.definition: A Sleeper transitions from a state of consciousness where they are largely unaware of their environment to a wakeful state.  'William awoke from a dream.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Place where the event occurs.
This FE identifies the sleeping entity.
This FE identifies the Time when the event occurs.
This describes the state out of which the Sleeper awakens. 'He awoke out of a deep dream.'
The Manner in which the Sleeper awakens.
The state of the Sleeper upon waking up. 'Well, sometimes she just wakes up angry.'
The New_situation is the situation the Sleeper finds him or herself in upon awaking.  'I awoke to the sound of the coffeegrinder.'
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
This FE indicates an instance of the Waking_up event within an iterated series of similar events or states.
The reason for which the Sleeper awakes from the Sleep_state.
This frame element is defined as the number of times an event occurs per some unit of time.

Jury_deliberation.definition: The Jury discuss the Case and its Charges in order to evaluate the  Possible_sentence of the accused.  'The jury deliberated his guilt.'

arguments.definition: The group that debates the case.
The amount of time for which the deliberation is ongoing.
The legal label for the crime that the defendant is accused of.
The Case which a trial is convened to decide.
When the deliberation takes place. 'The jury deliberated for three hours last Tuesday..'
Where the deliberation takes place. 'The jury deliberated for several hours in the Oakland courthouse.'
A sentence that the jury considers during deliberation. 'The jury deliberated his guilt.'

Sentencing.definition: During a court appearance, a Sentence, generally a punishment, is imposed on the Convict by a Court, usually represented by a judge.  'The judge sentenced Martha Stewart to 2 years in prison for insider trading.'

arguments.definition: The Convict is given a Sentence by the Court. 'Judge Duncan sentenced Marty to five years under house detention.'
The Court imposes a Sentence on a Convict. 'Judge Duncan sentenced Marty to five years under house detention.'
The Sentence is imposed on the Convict by the Court. 'Judge Duncan sentenced Marty to five years under house detention.'
This FE denotes the type of sentence. 'He will receive a prison sentence if convicted.'
This FE denotes the duration of the sentence. 'Tom will recieve a sentence of five years.'
The Time when the Convict is sentenced.  'He will be sentenced at a later date.'
The illegal action of which the Convict has been found guilty and for which they are punished.  'A pet store owner was sentenced for illegaly smuggling protected reptiles.'
The location of the sentencing Court.  'Biancaniello will be sentenced in San Francisco later this summer.'
The state that the Convict is  in at the time of their sentencing.  'He was sentenced in absentia during the mass trials.'

Text.definition: A Text is an entity that contains linguistic, symbolic information on a Topic, created by an Author at the Time_of_creation.  It may be a physical entity that is made of a certain Material etc.  It may be constructed for an Honoree.  'It was a good book.'

arguments.definition: The Author is the person who produced a particular Text.  'I'm glad I bought and read Robbins's book.'
The Text is the entity that contains linguistic information. This an incorporated FE for each LU in this frame.
The person for whom the Text is produced. 'The poem   for Caitlin was included in an anthology .'
The Time at which the Text was created.  'Jackson's new story is based on a 1980 novel by his father.' 'Poems from the end of that dynasty are known to contain many novel metric structures.'
What a Text is made of (if applicable). 'The library was so old, it was filled with vellum tomes, not a paperback in sight.'
This is a text in which the Text is located. 'The last poem in the anthology was horrid.'
The Genre or sub-Genre of the Text.  'She writes only historical fiction.'  'I've got three comedic screenplays on my desk right now!'
The use for which the text was produced; its purpose.   'She read through the bicycle's construction manual.'
The smaller texts that make up the Text. 'He found it in a book of spells.'
Topic is what the Text is about.'I read a book about knitting.'

The Title of a Text.  'She read Sassy magazine.' 'Current NOW President Kim Gandy said Friedan's Feminine Mystique book opened women's eyes.'  NOTE: when the Title is expressed in an appositive clause, it is labeled as Text on the first layer and Title on the second.  'She read the magazine Sassy.'

The Medium is the language in which a text is composed, or the physical medium (radio, ink) in which it is distributed.  'Science articles in Greek are difficult to understand for me.'  'It's prudent to pay attention to radio bulletins.'
The region where the Text is sold, circulated, or otherwise popular.
A characteristic of the Text

Body_decoration.definition: This frame concerns the decorations that human beings have on or apply to their bodies. 'Abby rarely wears lipstick.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the location on the body where the decoration takes place. 'Abby has a tattoo on her lower-back.'
This is the individual whose body is decorated. 'Abby rarely wears lipstick.'
Decoration is the decorative item that adorns the body. 'Abby has a tattoo on her thigh.'
Dec_desc identifies a descriptor of the Decoration. 'Abby wears red lipstick.'
This is the frame element that describes what shape the Decoration represents. 'Abby has a tattoo of a rose on her thigh.'
This FE identifies the Use to which a body decoration is put. 'Abby is wearing stage make-up.'
Type designates different kinds of body decorations.  Often this FE will label part of a multi-word or compound word target.  'Abby wore SPF 15 make-up to work, everyday.'

Predicament.definition: An Experiencer is in an undesirable Situation, whose Explanation may also be expressed.  'The insurers ended up in the bind of having to pay 15 years' taxes.'  'He was in a bit of a pickle and make no mistake!'  'What a mess we 're in now!'

arguments.definition: The Experiencer is in an undesirable Situation.  'The insurers ended up in a bind.'
This FE identifies the undesirable Situation the Experiencer is in. 'They found themselves in a quite a fix.' 'The company was definitely in dire straits from the dollar's inflation.'
This FE identifies the Explanation of  the Situation.  'We 're in this mess from paying too little attention to quality control.'
Thiis FE identifies the Time when the Situation is in effect.  'Yesterday's predicament was a little too exciting.'
The location where the Situation occurs.  'The trouble in America is only going to get worse.'
The Domain in which the Experiencer has the problem.

Rite.definition: This frame concerns rituals performed in line with religious beliefs or tradition.  'In certain fertility rites in Burma , a woman desirous of offspring is required not only to approach the King Cobra but to plant a kiss on its mouth .'  'He was ordered a priest in 1944. CNI '

arguments.definition: This is the religious or cultural leader who performs and/or leads the rite.  'The medicine man performs this ritual'
The FE Member describes the member of the religious or cultural group who participates in/undergoes the rite.  'Joe received communion.'
Organization identifies the institution in which the rite is prescribed.  'His baptism into the Catholic Church is scheduled for next Sunday.'
The action that is taken to perform the ritual.  'A building is consecrated by anointing the doorposts with special oil and saying certain prayers'
Manner of performing the rite
When the rite is performed
Where the rite takes place.
This FE identifies the Instrument used to perform a particular rite.  'We baptise children with holy water'
This FE identifies the state which the rite is hoped or intended to bring about. 'They performed a fertility ritual.'
The type of ritual or ceremony being performed.  'We performed the traditional marriage rites'
This FE indicates an object on which a rite is performed.  'The priest blessed the wine'
Rites may confer a New_status on a participant (e.g. rank, membership).  'Elliott was almost ordained as a priest'
The Guardian is the member of the Organization who instigates the rite for someone of which they are a guardian.  '<fex name = "Guardian">Mr. and Mrs. Wilson baptized their son.'

Physical_entity.definition: An Entity exists in some Place at some time.

arguments.definition: Salient parts or substances that make up an Entity.  At this level of abstraction, not every Entity is conceived of as having parts, though any normal entity has them.   'A bronze sword is nearly as strong as the steel ones .'
A thing (either abstract or physical) that exists with some degree of permanence.
Indicates the action (or causer) which made or makes the Entity what it is. 'glacial valley'
A label applied to a specific Entity.  Not usual for general words inheriting from this frame, but common for Locales.  'Keyboard 1 has all the right features .'

This FE indicates what subtype of the general category the Entity belongs to. When a subtype is signified by some more specific FE, like Formational_cause, we use that more specific FE instead of Type, so this FE is most often needed when there is a vague or unknown relation between a name that indicates the Type and the Type of Entity in question.  This FE is normally found as a pre-nominal modifier.  'We use only d'Arbin pottery .'
A place that a physical Entity is located with respect to.  'All the stuff on the bureau is small.'

Weather.definition: Ambient conditions of temperature, precipitation, windiness, and sunniness pertain at a certain Place and Time.  Further Specification of the conditions that pertain may also be indicated. 'A blustery storm blew in.' 'There was a thick blizzard last night.' 'An armada of hailstorms swept through the region.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Place where the weather occurs.
This FE identifies the Time when the weather occurs.
This FE identifies a further Specification of the weather conditions. 'An icy storm hit the Northeast last night.'

People.definition: This frame contains general words for Individuals, i.e. humans. The Person is conceived of as independent of other specific individuals with whom they have relationships and independent of their participation in any particular activity. They may have an Age, Descriptor, Origin, Persistent_characteristic, or Ethnicity.  ' A man from Phoenix was shot yesterday.'  ' She gave birth to a screaming babyyesterday.'  ' I study 16-year-old female adolescents.'  ' I am dating an African-American man.'  ' She comforted the terrified child.'  ' I always thought of him as a stupid man.'

arguments.definition: The Origin is the place where the Person was born or lived a salient part of her or his life.
The Person is the human being.
The Persistent_characteristic is a physiological characteristic or personality trait of the Person which is concieved of as persisting over time.
The Descriptor is a temporary condition of the Person.
The Age is the length of time the Person has been alive.
The Ethnicity is the religious, racial, national, socio-economic or cultural group to which the Person belongs.
An expression indicating the context with which the Person is associated.  'Hey, where'd that museum guy go?' 'Is that the woman from the rally?'

Attention_getting.definition: This frame covers terms used to get someone's attention, including Interjections (e.g. hey, yo) and certain terms of address (Address_term), the latter of which may serve the function of attention getting.    'Hey.' 'Hey, boy.' 'Hey, boy, come over here now!'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Address_term as used to get someone's attention, and may be a proper name. 'Boy, come over here right now!' 'Billy, come over here right now!'  Tag this constiuent with the FE Interjection on a secondary FE layer.
Interjection identifies the attention getting element. 'Hey, boy, come over here now!'

Becoming_attached.definition: An Item comes to be attached to a Goal, with a Connector forming a bond between the Handle of the Item and the Goal (or some part of it). Alternatively, multiple Items may form a bond between each other.  'According to plan, the front part of the hull quietly attached to the docking gear.'  'The cells bind together.'

arguments.definition: Connector identifies the  instrument used to attach, usually in a with-PP.  'The remoras attach to the whale with their strong jaws.'
Handle identifies the point of attachment on the Goal to which the Item attaches.  'The remoras attach by the mouth.'
Item identifies the entity that comes to be attached to the Goal.  'Remoras attached to the dolphins.'
Items identifies the plural items that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.  'The cells bind together.'
Goal identifies the location to which the first Item is attached.  'The remoras attach to the underside of the whale.'
This FE identifies the Result of an attaching event.  'The cells bind together.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Item comes to be attached to a Goal.
The location where the attaching event takes place.
The time when the attaching event takes place.

Being_attached.definition: An Item is attached by a Handle, via a Connector, to a Goal, or Items are attached to each other.  There may be a Dependent_state, which depends crucially on Item(s) being attached.  'My thumb was stuck to the tube of glue.'  'The prisoner's legs were shackled.'

arguments.definition: Connector identifies the instrument used to attach and is usually expressed in a with-PP.  'The tarp is  tied down with a rope.'
Handle identifies the point of attachment on the Item.  'Harry was tied by the neck to the tree.'
Item identifies the entity that comes to be attached to the Goal.  'A handle  was affixed to the door.'
Items identifies the plural items that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.  'The boats remained tied together.'
Goal identifies the location to which the Item(s) is attached.  'The boat remained anchored to the coastline.'
Dependent_state identifies the state of the Item or Items which depends on the existence of the attachment.  'The tarp is tied down with a cord.' 'Harry's hands are tied downwith cords.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Item is in an attached state to a Goal, or two Items are attached to each other.  'The tiny stick  was fastened tightly to his wrist.'

Reasoning.definition: An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.  The Content may refer elliptically to a course of action or it may refer to a proposition that the Addressee is to believe.  Some lexical units (e.g. "prove") indicate the speaker's belief about the Content.'Jan argued that the evidence was inadmissable.''Jan argued against the admissability of the evidence.''Jan proved  that the evidence was inadmissable.'

arguments.definition: The Arguer wants the Addressee to entertain the Content, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the Support presented.'Jan argued that the evidence was inadmissable.'
This FE identifies the physical or abstract setting in which the Content is conveyed.'Jan argued in writing that the evidence was inadmissable.'
The Arguer presents the Content before the Addressee.'Jan argued that the evidence was inadmissable.'
Addressee is the entity before whom the Arguer presents a Content. 'Jan argued to the court that the evidence was inadmissable.'
Support lends epistemic support to a claim, or provides a reason for a course of action.'Jan argued that gun was inadmissable as evidence because the police didn't have a search warrant.'
This FE identifes the Manner in which an Arguer argues.'Jan argued convincingly that the evidence was inadmissable. '
This FE identifies the Means by which an Arguer presents Content to an Addressee.'Jan argued the evidence was admissable by waving the warrant in the air.'
Depictive identifies a phrase describing a participant in an action.'Jan argued that the evidence was inadmissable in a tuxedo.'
This FE identifies the Result of an arguing event.
This FE identifies the Degree to which an arguing event occurs.'Jan argued the defendant's innocence beyond a shadow of a doubt.'
The Time at which an Arguer makes an argument for the Content.  ' The government argued in August that the prisoners should not be released'
This FE identifies the location where an argument is made by an Arguer.  'The young men will be arguing their policies in the school auditorium.'
The period of time for which the Arguer presents his or her reasoning to the Addressee.  'He argued for hours that chess is a sport '
An entity related to the Content.

Cause_to_be_wet.definition: An Agent causes a Patient to be wet with a Liquid.  In this frame, the Liquid can be a liquid or gas.  Patients are porous objects, but not hollow (like containers).  'Jo soaked the dog with water.' 'Ellen wet  the sponge with water.'

arguments.definition: The Agent is a volitional animate being who causes the Patient to become wet.  'Hannah drenched the cat with anti-flea ointment.'
The Liquid is a fluid or gas that permeates or covers the Patient.  It most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with.  'Jo soaked the dog with water.'
The Patient takes up the Liquid through its pores or has the Liquid covering its surface.  'Ellen wet  the sponge with water.'
This FE identifies the Manner or way in which the Agent wets the Patient.
This FE identifies the Means by which an the Agent wets the Patient
This FE identifies the Place where the Agent wets the Patient.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Agent wets the Patient and what the Agent hopes to accomplish.
This FE identifies the Time when the Agent wets the Patient.
This FE identifies the Instrument with which an Agent intentionally wets the Patient.  'Colin doused the burning pot with a fire extinguisher.'
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces the state of wetness.  'The sprinklers drenched me.'
Degree to which the Agent wets the Patient.  'Ryan doused the fire with water until it stopped smoldering.'
The Subregion describes which part of a larger whole is being affected.  'The cloth was wetted around the edges.'
This FE describes the reason for the state of the Cause_to_be_wet event.

Dead_or_alive.definition: A Protagonist is in the dynamic, maintained state of being alive or has exited this state.  'Frank's dead body was apalling.'

arguments.definition: Explanation identifies any object or event that brings about the death of the Protagonist.  'Within hours, Frank was dead of exposure.'
This FE identifies the Degree to which a Protagonist is dead or alive.
Protagonist identifies the being or entity that is  dead or alive. 'Frank was dead.'
This FE identifies the Figure or form being described by the target.  'Frank's dead body was apalling.'
The time in which the Protagonist is dead or alive.

Impact.definition: While in motion, an Impactor makes sudden, forcible contact with the Impactee, or two Impactors both move, mutually making forcible contact.   'The massive metal foot hit the ground with a huge thud.'

arguments.definition: Where the event takes place.
Result of an event
When the event occurs.
The reason for which an Impact occurs.
Manner of performing an action
The entity that hits the Impactee. 'The rock hit the sand with a thump.'
The entity which is hit by the Impactor. 'The rock hit the sand with a thump.'
The multiple entities that collide. 'The car and truck collided at a combined speed of over 100MPH.'
The speed at impact. 'The wrecking ball struck at 330 mph.'
Subregion identifies the affected part of the larger whole. 'The sparks hit the paper right on the edge.'
The amount of force in the course of the impact.
The Time throughout which the impact repeatedly takes place.
The state of the Impactors or the Impactor during the impact.

Detaining.definition: The Authorities hold a Suspect under suspicion of having committed a crime (Charges). The Holding_location and period of detention (Duration) may also be specified. 'The police held Mr. Smith in the slammer on charges of killing his lawyer.'

arguments.definition: The Authorities hold the Suspect in custody.
This FE identifies the crime with which the Suspect is charged.
Where the detaining takes place.
This FE identifies the person who is taken into custody and held, under suspicion of having committed a crime.
When the detaining occurs.
This FE identifies the place where the Suspect is confined. 'Marge was under arrest in the county jail.'
This FE identifies the length of time that the Suspect spends in confinement.
This FE identifies the law, act, or precedent that allows the Authorities  to detain the Suspect. 'The government held him under the Why Not Act.'
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Authorities detain a Suspect.
This FE identifies the state of the Suspect being held. 'Snake was held in communicado.'

Precipitation.definition: Water in some solid or liquid form (the Precipitation) falls from the sky at a particular Place and Time, lasting for a particular Duration.  The Rate or Quantity of precipitation may also be indicated.  'It rained in Berkeley yesterday.'

arguments.definition: The water in liquid or solid form that falls from the sky is the Precipitation. This FE is incorporated in many LUs in this frame.
The Quantity of Precipitation that falls within a certain Duration. 'It rains only half an inch per year around here.'

The Quantity is the amount of Precipitation that has fallen in a precipitation event or events.  It is usually measured as the height that the Precipitation attains if prevented from further movement. 'It rained six inches last night.'
The area which experiences precipitation.
The amount of time for which the precipitation event lasts.
When the event occurs. 'It will probably be raining at five o'clock.'
The Explanation is the reason for the precipitation event. 'It rains because of high humidity.'
The way in which the precipitation falls. 'It drizzled softly.'
This FE identifies the temperature of the precipitation. 'I was standing in the cool drizzle.'
This frame element is defined as the number of times an event occurs per some unit of time.

Coming_to_be.definition: An Entity comes into existence at a particular Place and Time which may take a certain Duration_of_endstate, have a Cause, or be formed from Components.  'Problems may arise whenever an S1 sophont enters the game.' 'Mountains sometimes form in as little as a million years.' 'A new paradigm emerged from the discussion of nuclear weapons.' 'New Plants form from the cut veins in two weeks.'

arguments.definition: Concrete or abstract entity that did not exist before the Time of the event.
This is the Place where the new Entity comes into being.
This FE identifes the Time when a new Entity comes into existence.
This FE labels the Explanation of the formation of the Entity. 'New clarity coalesced out of the hours spent simulating the climate.'
This FE identifies the components out of which the Entity forms. 'New plants form from cut veins in two weeks.'
This FE identifies the length of time that the Entity exists after coming to be.
The form in which the Entity comes to be. 'Vishnu materialized in the form of a half man, half beast.' 'The megacorps stranglehold on property emerged as a problem.'
This FE identifies the Period_of_iterations during which habitual or iterative actions are performed.
The way in which the Entity comes to be.

Releasing.definition: A Captor ends the captivity or inhibition of the motion of a Theme from the Location_of_confinement. The release is in accord with the plans of the Captor.  'They released me from prison on New Year's Day.'

arguments.definition: The Captor is the individual who ends the confinement or captivity of the Theme. The release of the Theme is in accord with the plans of the Captor.  'The police released the suspect.'
The Theme is the person or object in motion released by the Captor.  'The police released the suspect.'

Any description of the release which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of an Captor that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).   'The police released the suspect carefully.'
The action of the Captor which brings about the release.  'He released a hundred prisoners by signing a single document..'
The Explanation identifies the reason for which the Captor are releasing the Theme.  'The police released the suspect  because he had a good alibi.'
The Purpose identifies the purpose for which the Captor release the Theme.
The location where the Theme ceases to be confined.  '"Aren't you going to release us here?" she asked.'
The Time identifies when the Captor release the Theme .
The location to which the Theme's motion was formerly inhibited.  'She petitioned unsuccessfully for their release from Chateau D'If.'

This FE signifies that the state of affairs expressed by the main clause (containing the target) occurs or holds, and something other than that state of affairs would be expected given the state of affairs in the concessive clause.
The state of the world when the Releasing event occurs.

Verdict.definition: In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.  'He was convicted of fraud by Judge Judy.'

arguments.definition: The Judge (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the Finding.
This FE identifies the outcome of the Judge's deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This FE refers to the Charges with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The Case on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
This FE indicates the basis in law of a verdict. 'He was found guilty under section 28 article 5.'
The Circumstances under which the verdict was reached. 'He was convicted on a four to three vote.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which the Judge acts.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Judge returns a particular verdict. 'Did you acquit him just to get the publicity?'
This FE identifies an action that the Judge performs in order to return the verdict.
The Explanation for the verdict given. 'The jury convicted him on all charges because of the overwhelming evidence against him.'

Creating.definition: A Cause leads to the formation of a Created_entity.  'Dr. Frankenstein created a monster.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the Components that are attached together to form a Created_entity. 'The force of the rock above formed diamond out of the carbon.'
This FE identifies the entity that the Agent intentionally creates. 'They were assembling grenades for export.'
This FE identifies a depictive phrase describing the actor or undergoer of an action. We wandered around naked. Cicadas screech unseen from within.
This FE identifies the Means by which a Creator intentionally creates a new entity.
This FE identifies the Manner in which a Creator intentionally creates a new entity.
This FE identifies the place ehere the Agent intentionally creates the new entity.
This FE identifes the Time when an Agent intentionally creates a new entity.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that produces an effect. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of Causes.
This FE identifies the instrument with which an Agent intentionally creates a Created_entitiy.
A secondary agent with whom the Creator intentionally creates the Created_entity.
The Creator creates a created entity.
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Creator intentionally creates a new entity.
The Creator's intended purpose for the Created_entity.
The Beneficiary benefits in some way from the creation of the Created_entity.
The Role that the Created_entity takes (or is intended to take, if there is a Creator).
The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
This frame element is defined as the number of times an event occurs per some unit of time.
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
The individual who is intended to receive the Created_entity.  'She made me this hammock.'

Try_defendant.definition: A Defendant is tried by a Jury or Judge in a Court for Charges.  This frame perspectivalizes the general Trial frame.  'The state will try him for fraud.'

arguments.definition: The Judge heads the Court where the case is tried.  An expression referring to the Court may also stand in for the Judge. 'Judge Murphy will try the defendant for murder.' 'The court is currently trying several South American militants on charges of vehicular manslaughter.'
This FE identifies the Court in which a case is tried.
The Defendant is being tried for the Charges in Court.
This FE identifies the people who are charged by the Court to listen to the testimony, evidence, and arguments, and come to a consensus about the guilt or innocence of the Defendant.
This FE identifies the Time when the case is tried.
This FE identifies the Place where the case is tried.
This FE identifies the Charges brought against the Defendant.
The Defendant is tried under the laws of the Governing_authority. 'The United States will try the accused bomber in a federal courthouse.'
The Manner of the trial of the Defendant. 'Thomas Klein was tried in absentia.'

Employment_scenario.definition: An Employee and Employer enter into an employment relation, wherein the Employee remains employed for some Duration of time, and finally the relationship ends either by the Employee leaving the job or the Employer letting go (or firing) the Employee.  To each of these events there are concomitants, such as agreeing to/signing a contract for entering employment, compensation and performance of a service for the employment period itself, and severance for the dissolution of the relationship.  There are several other events involved, including preparatory actions on the part of the Employer (posting the Position), the prospective Employee's part (looking for a job), or both (job interviews).  In addition, there is the possibility of change in the relationship of Employer and Employee during the employment period, such as a change in Position (e.g. promotion, demotion) and a change in Compensation (e.g. raise, paycut).

arguments.definition: Compensation is the payment that the Employee receives for performing a Task.
The person who is obligated to perform some Task in order to receive Compensation.  'I was just hired yesterday!'
The person (or institution) that gives Compensation to an Employee.
The label given to a particular type of employment. 'Look, I wasn't hired as your waitress!'
Task identifies the action that the Employee is obligated to do for the Employer.  'I was hired just to empty the trash cans.'
This FE identifies the Field in which one works. 'He has been working in finance for years.'
This FE identifies the amount of time for which the Employee continues in employ.

Hiring.definition: An Employer hires an Employee, promising the Employee a certain Compensation in exchange for the performance of a job.  The job may be described either in terms of a Task or a Position.  In some cases, the Employee FE will also indicate the Position (see fourth example below).  'John was hired to clean up the file system.' 'IBM hired Gates as chief janitor.' 'I was retained at $500 an hour.' 'The A's signed a new third baseman for $30M.' The same sentence (above) should also have the FE Position on the second layer: 'The A's signed a new third baseman for $30M.'

arguments.definition: The person whom the Employer takes on as an Employee, obligating them to perform some Task in order to receive Compensation.  'I was just hired yesterday!'

The person (or institution) that takes on an Employee, giving them  Compensation in return for the performance of an assigned Task.  'Last month, IBM hired Mike Zisman to head up its storage software group.'

The Compensation is the payment that the Employee is set to receive  for performing an assigned Task.  'They fired our management, hired him for 20% more and gave him a free office to set up his own company.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Employer hires an Employee.  'The three young men were given medals and hastily commissioned'.
This FE identifies the place where the Employer hires the Employee.  'Actually, he hired me in a bordello.'
This FE identifies the Time when an Employer hires the Employee.  'Guess who just got hired today!'
This FE identifies the Purpose for which an Employer hires the Employee.  'John hired her to make his wife jealous.'
The action that the Employee is taken on by the Employer to do.  'I was hired just to empty the trash cans.'
The label given to a particular type of employment.  'Look, I wasn't hired as your waitress!'
The Field that the Employee is going to work in for their Employer.  'It's not easy to get hired in academia.'
An entity that the Employer uses to hire the Employee.   'The congressman hired him with personal funds as an aide. '
An action by the Employer whereby the hire is brought about.  'The manager hired me with a handshake.'

The Contract_basis is the condition of employment with respect to permanency, hours per time period or payment arrangements.   'She couldn't figure it out but suggested that I'd be good for the job, so they hired me part time at first.'
The length of time from when the hiring event began to be repeated to when it stopped.

Employing.definition: An Employer employs an Employee whose Position entails that the Employee perform certain Tasks in exchange for Compensation.  'I employed him as Chief Gardener for ten years.'

arguments.definition: The Compensation is the payment that the Employee receives for performing a Task.
The FE Employee denotes the person who is obligated to perform some Task in order to receive Compensation.  'I was employed by an international corporation.'
The Employer is the person (or institution) that gives Compensation to an Employee.  'I employed him as Chief Gardener for ten years.'
The FE Field identifies the field in which the Employee is employed.  'He was employedin finance fourteen years ago.'
The FE Manner identifies the way in which an Employer hires an Employee.  'The three young men were given medals and hastily commissioned.'
The FE Place identifies the location where the Employer hires the Employee.  'Actually, he employed me  at the downtown office .'
The FE Position indicates a particular type of employment.  'I'm not employed as your waitress!'
The FE Purpose identifies what the Employer intends to accomplish through the hiring of the Employee.  'John employs bodyguards to protect him from previous clients.'
The Task indicates the action/duty that the Employee is obligated to do for the Employer.  'I am employed to collect the trash.'
The FE Time identifies the time at whcih the Employer hires the Employee.  'Charles has been an employee of Microsoft since 1998!'
The FE Duration identifies the amount of time for which the Employee continues in employ.  'I employed him as Chief Gardener for ten years.'
The Contract_basis is the condition of employment with respect to permanency, hours per time period or payment arrangements.  'Chrysler employs 1000 skilled worker full-time.'

This FE describes a characteristic of the Employee.  'Electronic theft by foreign and industrial spies and disgruntled employees is costing U.S. companies billions and eroding their international competitive advantage.'
The Subgroup is the department or subdivision of the institution that the Employee is a member of. 'He is an employee in the marketing department.'

Get_a_job.definition: A new Employee obtains a Position with an Employer, with which there are certain Tasks associated; in exchange for the performance of these Tasks, the Employee receives Compensation from the Employer.  'I signed on with YouTube to make them a new GUI.'

arguments.definition: The Compensation is the payment that the Employee receives for performing a Task.  'He said he wanted to play for a contender, and then he signed on for a lot of money with a team that is not a contender.'

The person who enters an employment relation with an Employer.  'In spring of 1983, Tom signed on at the historic Wawona Hotel in Yosemite National Park, and continues to perform there nightly in the hotel's piano parlor.'

The person (or institution) that the Employee enters an employment relationship with.   'He later played for the Scottish Claymores of the NFL Europe League in the spring of 2001, then signed on with Baltimore in July of 2001.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Employee enters an employment relationship with an Employer.   'Van Auken eagerly signed on with Pennsylvania.'
This FE identifies the place where the Employee enteres an employment relationship with an Employer.  'I had signed on right there with the rest of the freaks. '
The label given to a particular type of employment.  ' In 1973 Franco Acerbis signed on as a mechanic for the Italian enduro team.'
This FE identifies the purpose for which an Employee enters an employment relationship.   'Aengaela signed on with the Company to learn the family business. '
The action that the Employee is obligated to do for the Employer.   'In the end, however, Gaskill opted to remain out West and signed on to play Oscar Marone on CBS's The Bold and the Beautiful.'
This FE identifies the Time when an Employee signs on with an Employer.    'Things have been very busy with the new job since I signed on in June, 2001.'
The action by which the Employee enters an employment relationship.  'After interviewing, he signed on with a handshake in 1988.'

The Contract_basis is the condition of employment with respect to permanency, hours per time period or payment arrangements.   'In addition, Kellie Anngotell and Emil Fredette have hired on part-time. '

Quitting.definition: An Employee voluntarily leaves the service of an Employer.  'Leah quit her job after one month because of an evil force.'  ' It's Time for Glenn Hubbard to Quit as CEA Chair' 'Its chief executive officer has resigned amid a reorganization that will also eliminate about 20 percent of its work force.' 'Its chief executive officer has resigned amid a reorganization that will also eliminate about 20 percent of its work force.' 'You should fill in your name, the defendant's name, and the date and time you gave notice. DNI'

arguments.definition: The person who is obligated to perform some task in order to receive compensation.  'I just quit yesterday!'
The person (or institution) in whose employ  the Employee stood.  'He replaces Michael Lawrie, 50, who quit IBM to run Siebel.'
The Field that one works in. 'He might quit showbusiness for years.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Employee leaves the job.   ' Los Angeles junior high school teacher named Patricia Ann Carruthers quit her job in a huff.'
This FE identifies the place where the Employee quits the employment of the Employer.  'Actually Iquit  in the lobby before I got to my office.'
The label given to a particular type of service that the employer quits. ' I  quit as a professional player!'
This FE identifies the purpose for which an Employee quits the employment of the Employer. 'John resigned  to join the private sector.'
This FE identifies the Time when an Employee quits the employment of the Employer.  'Guess who just quit today!'
The Explanation for which the Employee quits.  'North quit over the mismanagement scandal.'
The means whereby the act of quitting is accomplished 'Lately, many workers have been quitting by simply not showing up for work.'

Firing.definition: An Employer ends an employment relationship with an Employee.  There is often a Reason given for the action.  'He fired me as annotator for being too slow.'

arguments.definition: The person who is let go by their Employer.    'I was just fired yesterday!'

The person (or institution) that end an employment relationship with an Employee.  'Dominic Mallozzi claims United Trust Bank fired him from a job at the bank's Palmer Township branch because he's HIV positive.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which an Employer fires an Employee.  'Five were hastily fired, and the federal government is investigating possible insider trading violations.'
This FE identifies the Place where the Employer fires the Employee.  'The phone in his small apartment in the town of Milan rang and he dreaded it. He was going to be fired right there.'
The label given to a particular type of employment.   'Doc Rivers was fired as coach of the Orlando Magic.'
This FE identifies the Purpose for which an Employer fires the Employee.  'John fired her to make his the other employees nervous.'
The action that the Employee is relieved from doing for the Employer  .'I was fired from training the new actors.'
This FE identifies the Time when an Employer fires the Employee.  'Guess who just got fired today!'
The Explanation for which the Employee is terminated.   'North was dismissed for gross mismanagement of funds.'
The means whereby the Employer fires the Employee  'Pat fired Jan by leaving a letter of dismissal on his desk.'

Part_inner_outer.definition: This frame concerns Parts of objects that are defined relative to the center or edge of the object.  The Part is a part of the Whole and the Part_prop describes a property of the Part.  'She discarded the exterior of the walnut.' ' She preferred a sparse church interior . '  In cases where the Target is an adjective, it has a special relationship with the noun that it modifies such that a phrase which is a syntactic argument of the noun is semantically available to fill the argument structure of the adjective, as in "the outside row of the class"'The inner shelf of the bookcase was lying on the floor.'

arguments.definition: This element describes the Part of the larger Whole.'She only ate the skin of the apple.'
An undivided entity having all its Parts.'She eats only the thick skin of the banana.'
A property relating to the Part of a Whole.'Sue ate the thick shell of the pistachio.'

Shapes.definition: This frame contains words which describe the dimensional extent and Shape of a Substance.  These words do not make reference to a Part-whole relationship. There can also be a descriptor of the Shape, Shape_prop.  'She held a square of cloth .'

arguments.definition: A Substance of which pieces can be extracted.'Sue ate a big square of cake.'
This is the Shape that the Substance is in.'I ate a stick of butter.'
This describes a property of the Shape, e.g. it's size.'Sue ate a big square of cake.'
The number of units of the measured Substance. 'Serena found two squares of coth in the cabinet.'

Boundary.definition: This frame contains words that describe a Boundary between two Entities.  In many cases, the Boundary is the border between an Entity and some unnamed space, generally conceived of as empty.  'The canyon is the border between the two states.'

arguments.definition: The region which is between the Entities or between the Entity and empty space.
The entity that has a Boundary.
The joint construal of both Entities next to the Boundary.
The relative location of the boundary in respect to the Entity or Entities.

Part_edge.definition: This describes a part_whole relationship where the Part provides the boundary between the Whole and what is not that object.  The Part can exist along a continuum of width.  It can be modified by an Orientation that specifies the particular portion of the edge of a Part_prop which describes a property of the Part.   'We came to the southern edge  of the town  . '
