An entity which participates in a Cause, perhaps volitionally and perhaps not, but effectively causing the interruption.  'In such cases the server will automatically interrupt the process.'
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
Any holistic description of the event, including overall depictions (the same way) and descriptions pertaining to the Actor or Cause's influence on the character of the event.
The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows. This often means that the Explanation causes the target's proposition, but not in all cases.
An action or sub-event through which the Actor or Cause interrupts the Process.
How often the interruption occurs.

This FE signifies that the state of affairs expressed by the main clause (containing the target) occurs or holds, and something other than that state of affairs would be expected given the state of affairs in the concessive clause.

Temporal_collocation.definition: A Trajector is identified as occurring at the same time as some better-known Landmark.  We consider sequenced calendric units (e.g. Tuesday, 1987, January) as periods for the purposes of this frame.  Some lexical items allow certain types of frame elements while disallowing others (e.g. *During Tuesday...).  Several words of this frame (e.g. now.adv) have deictic incorporation of the Landmark_period.  'He tried to take care of that on his last visit .' 'I especially like brunch on Sunday.' 'Dinosaurs lived in prehistoric eras.'  'He did it then.'

arguments.definition: The entity that occurs at some time.  'The current President of Georgia was born in Tbilisi.'  'Books in the early 19th century had fewer pictures.'
The event which designates the time at which a trajector occurs.  'During last night's walk , I stubbed my toe.'
This FE describes the state of affairs reported by the target is understood to play a role in the state of affairs of the modifier.
The period that occurs with respect to some other time.  'Future eras will be vastly changed from today.'

The period in which a trajector takes place.  This period can be cyclical and, in that case, is interpreted contextually.  'I went to the store on Tuesday.' 'In the Triassic Era, the first flying vertebrates appeared.'
The event that occurs at some time.  'Currently, researchers are making new discoveries very quickly.'
The entity which designates the time of some trajector.  Note: this FE is infrequent or non-existent in English and is included for completeness.

Simultaneity.definition: Two Events happen at the same time.  This may either be construed symmetrically as a relation holding between the Events, or asymmetrically as holding between a Landmark_event whose known occurrence is used to describe when a Profiled_event took place.  'These events coincided.'

arguments.definition: The event which is asserted to occur at the same time as the Landmark_event.
The event or time period whose timing the Profiled_event is judged against.
The states-of-affairs which are asserted to be co-timed.
The degree to which the Profiled_event and Landmark_event coincide.  'The attacks on the palace nearly coincided with the beginning of peace talks.'

Attempt_distant_interaction_scenario.definition: An Agent attempts to interact with a relatively distant or indirectly accessible Target using some Instrument (which may be a body part, e.g. hand).  The Agent's ability to manipulate the Instrument and put it in the Target location is in question.  The most common types of distant interaction involve an Agent attempting to move the Instrument ballistically so that it contacts the Target (e.g. Shooting_scenario), or an Agent attempting to direct an Instrument that enables perception at a Target_location to be examined.

arguments.definition: The Agent tries to interact with the Target.
The Target is the entity located in an indirectly accessible location relative to the Agent.
The Outcome is the failure or success of an attempt.
This FE identifies the Means by which an attempt occurs.
This FE identifies the Degree to which an attempt occurs.
This FE identifies the Time when the attempt occurs.
The Depictive is a phrase which describes the Agent during the event.
The place where an attempt is made.
The Manner in which the Agent makes the attempt.
The time peiod over which the attempt or attempts take place.
The reason for which the Agent attempts to interact with the Target

Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states. In addition, most expressions of Particular_iteration indicate which instance of the series is being referred to.
The state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is independent of the the attempt of the Agent.
The object manipulated by the Agent in order to interact with the Target.
The location that the Agent is attempting to access using the Instrument.

Aiming.definition: An Agent adjusts an Instrument to enable it to interact directly with a difficult-to-access Target_location.  Usually, there is a Targeted entity at the Target_location which is mentioned in its place.  'If you aim your weapons somewhere else , I 'll be more likely to talk .' 'The sortie targeted primarily resupply points , but these included several civilian areas . INI' 'A good marksman still should take aim for a moment before each shot . INI INI'

arguments.definition: The individual that manipulates the Instrument to enable interaction with the Targeted.
The Targeted is the entity located in an indirectly accessible location relative to the Agent.  'I tried to target his left thigh .'
The Outcome is the failure or success of an attempt.
This FE identifies the Means by which the aiming is achieved.
This FE identifies the Time when the Agent takes aim.
The Depictive is a phrase which describes the Agent during the event.
The place where the Agent aims at the Targeted.

Any generalized description of the details of the event in terms of comparison to another event or what would be expected of the details given some state of the Agent.  'She took careful aim before shooting .'
The time peiod over which the adjustment of the Instrument takes place.
The reason for which the Agent attempts to interact with the Targeted

Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states. In addition, most expressions of Particular_iteration indicate which instance of the series is being referred to.
The state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is independent of the the aiming of the Agent, but contextualizes it.
The object manipulated by the Agent in order to interact with the Targeted.
The location that the Agent wishes to ready the Instrument to access.  'If you target towards the bridge , make sure to avoid the church .'

The location from which the proto-agent acts or perceives.  This does not include the location of a thing which is affected or perceived in the event.  'With remote drones , you can target Moscow <fex name="">from your own living room .'
The Activity is undertaken by the Agent and is directed towards the Targeted or Target_location.  'The attack targeted a village south of here.'
A larger event during which an aiming event takes place.  'Milatary convoys were targeted by rebels in several attacks over the past week.'
A state of affairs that provides an explanation for the Aiming event.  'They were targeted because they were the most prominent supporters of the establishment.'

Hit_or_miss.definition: An Agent succeeds or fails to interact perceptually or physically with the Target or Target_location.  The Instrument which is used to interact with the Target may stand in metonymically for the Agent.  'At first he shot very wide of his target .' 'Because I programmed the scope wrong , I kept missing Jupiter .' 'She scored two hits on the deer 's left side .'

arguments.definition: The individual who tries to interact with the Target.
The Target is the entity located in an indirectly accessible location relative to the Agent.
The Outcome is the failure or success of an attempt at interaction, incorporated in the LUs of the frame.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent achieves a Purpose.
This FE identifies the Degree to which the interaction takes place at the Target_location.
This FE identifies the Time when something hits or misses.
A description of the Agent during the event.
The place where the Agent manages or fails to interact with the Target.
Any description of how the details of the event compare to others, either generally (the same way), or in terms of a state of the Agent which influences the event (carelessly).
The reason for which the Agent attempts to interact with the Target

Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states. In addition, most expressions of Particular_iteration indicate which instance of the series is being referred to.
The state of the world (at a particular time and place) which contextualizes the hitting or missing of the Agent but is not conceived of as caused by it.
The object manipulated by the Agent in order to interact with the Target.
The location that the Agent is attempting to access using the Instrument.
The number of times that the Agent hits or misses the Target.
The distance of the actual location from the Target_location.

Accuracy.definition: An Agent is involved in an activity whose degree of success is dependent on a parameter of the action matching a particular set of values of a continuous variable or variables (e.g. quantity, location, time).    The Agent, or metonymically the Instrument or Means action, is described in terms of the actual or expected Deviation between the location, time, or quantity in the activity and the location, time, or quantity which is necessary for the intended event.  'The Longview Rangefinder is accurate to within one foot per hundred yards .' 'His estimate was off by an order of magnitude .'  'The fork truck operator must be fairly accurate in his aim.'  'The precision of the daily measurements is dependent on a number of factors.'

arguments.definition: The individual who tries to interact with the Target.  'The mailman is very exact about addresses -- he has to be .'
The Target is the entity whose attributes (esp. position) the Agent is attempting to match in an action.
The Outcome is the failure or success of an attempt at interaction, incorporated in the LUs of the frame.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent attempts to hit a Target_value.
How closely the expected or actual location that the Instrument interacts with corresponds to the Target_value.
This FE identifies the Time when something hits or misses.
The place where the Agent manages or fails to interact with the Target.
The object manipulated by the Agent in order to interact with the Target.
The value or values for a parameter that match the Agent's intent.
Expected or actual deviation from the Target_value.  'For this they would need a thermometer accurate to within a microkelvin. '
The particular aspect or domain in which something is accurate.
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
How often the Agent, Means, or Instrument is accurate.

Lively_place.definition: A Location is characterized by a high amount of (often goal-oriented) Activity, or metonymically, with Individuals who are engaged in the activity.  'The park was abuzz with people.'

arguments.definition: The Location where a lot of activity is taking place, or prototypically takes place.
A modifier expressing  the deviation in amount of activity from the norm or from the amount for another Location.
The Time during which the Location is characterized by a lot of activity.
Some specification of the circumstances under which the Location has some degree of activity or liveliness.
The larger or general area where the Location is lively.  'On this side of town the streets are livelier.'
The Activity that is conceptually filling the Location.
The Individuals are engaged in the Activity, creating a lively Location.

Duration denotes the length of time from the beginning of a continuous situation (the one denoted by the target) to its end. In many cases, the continuous situation is a dynamic action which is ongoing, while in others it is simply an undifferentiated state.
The way in which the Individuals or Location is engaging in the Activity.

The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the main clause (headed by the target) logically follows. This often means that the Explanation causes the state of affairs expressed by the target, but not in all cases.

Cause_proliferation_in_number.definition: An Agent (or inanimate Cause) affects a Set so that the number of entities that make up the Set changes from an Initial_number to a Final_number. Alternatively, the situation can be described in terms of an Initial_state and a Final_state. In some cases the Attribute (i.e., number) or Difference in number may be mentioned.  'More and more resources have been devoted to halting rogue nation's proliferation of controlled nuclear technology.'

arguments.definition: The person who causes the Set to increase in number.
The distance between the orginal value (Initial_number) and the final value (Final_number) of the Set.
The scale along which the Set ranges in, i.e., number.
The initial number of entities in the Set.
The final number of entities in the Set.
The Co-Variable is the scale that the amount of the Set is measured against.
Any expression that says something about the movement of the entity (Set) along the scale between its Initial_number and its Final_number.
The rate at which the entity's positon on the scale changes.
The entity whose amount is being changed.
An act performed by the Agent that brings about the change in the number of the Set.
The purpose for which the proliferating of the number of a Set is performed.
When the proliferating occurs.
The force that causes the change.

Any description of the Agent changing the number of the Set which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of an Agent that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
The location where the Agent changes the number of the Set.
The state of the Set before it is affected by an outside Agent or Cause.
The state of the Set after it is affected by an outside Agent or Cause.

Individual_history.definition: This scenario describes a series of Events, associated with a single Participant, i.e., the history of the Participant. The Events do not necessarily form a coherent whole (e.g., are not necessarily causally related), but merely occupy a period of time. In many cases the history is limited to what are considered the important or significant events. Words in this frame can also denote the time period over which the sequence of Events took place.  Note: uses of words in this frame to describe a record of the series of events are not in this frame (e.g., we compiled a history of Rome).  'We've been worried about our recent hire's history of deceiving employers.'  'The following sections document the entire 25-year history of the company.'  'Our areas of strength are British, American and European History from 1492 to 2000.'

arguments.definition: The Participant is either an active participant in all of the Events (e.g., Agent or Patient), or is more peripherally associated with the Events (e.g., Location or Topic).  'We've been worried about our recent hire's history of deceiving employers.'  'I was charmed, and also determined to learn more about the factory's history.'
The Events which the Participant is a part of. This FE is used to mark the frame-evoking element.  'We will focus on events in her recent history.'

The Domain is (a characterization of) the type of event that is to be included in consideration of the Participant's history.  'One of my colleagues is an expert on the economic history of the Hellenistic period'  'The Netherlands' long history of trade with China provides important information for modern political economies.'
The end of the span of time during which the Events occur.  'This article discusses mainly the geography and the history of Palestine until the United Nations took up the Palestine problem in 1947.'
The beginning of the time span over which the Events occur.  'The introduction describes the history of geography from the eighteenth century onwards.'
The span of time over which the Events take place.  'We have traced the flag?s past between its original conception in the 14th century and its end a hundred years later.'
The Duration, often expressed in calendric units, of the history of the Participant.  'The following sections document the entire 25-year history of the company.'
A characterization of the Participant or Events.
When the Events concerning the Participant occured.

Touring.definition: A Tourist experiences an Attraction, a location with a unique history or other societally recognized individual character, with the goal of seeing and learning about it. Typically, the Attraction has a source of information about the Attraction--a guide, pamphlets, or displays.  'We toured the Grand Canyon.'

arguments.definition: The individual that is seeking an experience at an Attraction.
The societally-recognized unique location that the Tourist experiences.
The state of the Tourist or the Attraction during the tour.
The perceptual background against which the Attraction is experienced by the Tourist.
Any description of the details of the event in terms of how they compare to other events (the same way) or in terms of how the state of the Tourist affects them (happily, obliviously).
The Means indicates a method the Tourist is using to participate in a tour.
The time that the touring takes place.
Some action that the Tourist is trying to accomplish with touring.  This is generally (at a minimum) for the purposes of entertainment and learning.
The location where the touring takes place.
The amount of  time the touring activity lasts.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
The Co-participant is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the touring event with the Tourist.

Historic_event.definition: In the course of history, an Event or Entity is taken to have importance or significance.  'Throughout the campaign activists have made financial history as one by one major corporations have yielded to protester power'  'The conference was historic for Atlanta's growth as a city.'  'Many of the historic sites offer additional outdoor recreation activities.'  'The James River is arguably the most historic river in the country and one of the most important rivers in the Southeast.'  'Take in the history, the sawdust-covered floors, and the legendary backroom where the ale flowed during Prohibition.'

arguments.definition: This FE identifies the event which occurs to create history.
This FE identifies where the event takes place.
This FE identifies the time when the event occurs.
This FE identifies the Explanation for which an event occurs.
This FE identifies the entity, concrete or abstract.
Any description of the event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly) and general descriptions comparing events (the same way).

The Domain is (a characterization of) the type of event that is part of the Event's history.  'Throughout the campaign activists have made financial history as one by one major corporations have yielded to protester power'
This frame element selects some gradable attribute and modifies the expected value for it.

Visiting.definition: An Agent matches location with an Entity in order to fulfill some  Purpose.  Quite often, the Purpose is social- or entertainment-oriented.  'I ca n't remember how many times he visited ! DNI' 'Now she was on an inspection visit .' 'You have to visit your parents every once in a while .'

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that is temporarily with the Entity in order to fulfil some Purpose.
The physical entity that is permanently associated with entities or characteristics that the Agent wishes to use for some Purpose.  During the visit, the Agent matches location with the Entity.
A state (of the Agent) that results as a consequence of the Agent being situated at the Entity.
The activity that is enabled by the Entity and that the Agent wishes to achieve.
The location that the Agent normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.
The time at which a visit is made.
The amount of time that the Agent spends with the Entity.
Any overall description of the details of the visit, either in terms of how it matches other events (the same way) or in terms of states of the Agent that affect the action.
A description of the position of the Agent during the visit.
An action of the Agent that enables their visit.
The number of instances of the described event.
A characterization of the average number of times a visit happens over a period of time.
A description of the state of Agent or Entity during the action.

Visitor_scenario.definition: An Agent leaves their Normal_location and matches location with an Entity in pursuit of a Purpose.  The Agent temporarily remains with the Entity to fulfil this Purpose and then departs again, usually back to the Normal_location.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that heads toward and is temporarily with the Entity in order to fulfil some Purpose.
A place that is permanently associated with entities or characteristics that the Agent wishes to use for some Purpose.
The activity that is enabled by the Entity and that the Agent wishes to achieve.
The location that the Agent normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.

Visitor_arrival.definition: An Agent arrives at a Goal that should enable their Purpose.

arguments.definition: Agent is the object that moves under its own power.

Normal_location is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion. While Normal_location expressions are possible in this frame, they are relatively infrequent.  If present, they often express a general direction from which a Agent moves, rather than a landmark away from which it moves.
Path is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Normal_location nor a Goal.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a via-sense.

Goal is any expression that tells where the Agent ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.  Although always conceptually present and specific, Goal may sometimes be understood from context, rather than expressed by any separate constituent. 'Our visitors arrived yesterday.'

A Manner expression  describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion.  Descriptions of speed, steadiness, grace, means of motion, and other things count as Manner expressions.
This FE identifies the Means by which an Agent arrives.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Agent is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Agent.   Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.  'I reached Canada by car.'  'I reached Mexico on foot.'
This FE identifies the Time when arriving occurs.
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Agent arrives at the Goal.
The place where the arrival occurs.

Visitor_departure.definition: After a visit is complete, the Agent departs the Source, normally bound for their normal haunts.

arguments.definition: This is the individual which moves under their own power.
Any constituent that expresses the initial position of the Agent, before the change of location, is tagged with Source. Often the Source is understood from context.
Any description of the trajectory of the departure which is neither a Source nor a Goal expresses the frame element Path.
This FE labels any expression which tells where the Agent ends up, or would end up, as a result of departing from the Source.

Any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion expresses the frame element Manner. Descriptions of steadiness, grace, and many other things count as Manner expressions, though Speed and Means should be tagged using the more specific FE labels.
The action of the Agent which results in their departure.
This frame element labels words or phrases that describe how quickly the Agent is moving.
The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Agent is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Agent. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium.
The distance that the Agent has traveled.
The Time at which the departure takes place.
The Place is the location in  which the departing takes place.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Agent departs from the Source.

Provide_lodging.definition: A Host provides a temporary Residence for a Lodger.  'We housed her in our home for a while.'

arguments.definition: The Host is the individual (or group of individuals) that own or control the Residence and allow the  Lodger to temporarily stay there.
The Lodger is the individual who is given permission to lodge in the Residence.
The Circumstances are the conditions under which the Host provides lodging.
The Time is when the Host provides a Residence to the Lodger
The Place is where the Host provides a temporary Residence.
The Purpose is the goal of the Host in allowing the Lodger to stay.
The Explanation is the cognitive cause of the Host's granting of permission.

Any description of the provision of lodging which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In addition, it may indicate salient characteristics of the Host that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).
An action of the Host whereby they communicate or enact the granting of permission to stay in the Residence.  ''
The location controlled by the Host which the Lodger stays at temporarily.

Lodging_scenario.definition: A Host provides a Residence for a Lodger to temporarily stay.

arguments.definition: The Host is the individual (or group of individuals) that own or control the Residence and allow the  Lodger to temporarily stay there.
The Lodger is the individual who is given permission to lodge in the Residence.
The Time is when the Host provides a Residence to the Lodger
The Place is where the Host provides a temporary Residence.
The location controlled by the Host which the Lodger stays at temporarily.

Aging.definition: An Entity is undergoing a change in age typically associated with some deterioration or change in state.   'This bark ages and turns black.'  'The U.S. is to upgrade aging missile defense systems with advanced tech.'

arguments.definition: The Entity which is undergoing aging.
The Time during which the Entity ages.
Some specification of the circumstances under which the Entity undergoes the aging event.

Any description of the event (or state) which is not covered by more specific FEs, including force (hard, softly), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). In agentive frames, it may indicate salient characteristics of an intentional Theme that affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully).  'These kinds of condoms aged quickly.'
This FE indicates where the Entity is located.
The end Result of the Entity aging.

Locale_by_event.definition: A place defined in terms of an event which occurred (or will occur) there. 'Woodstock, NY was the site of the most important rock concert of 1969.' 'Our meeting site was chosen for its solitude.'  In the second example, the event FE is labeled with two labels, because the two words do not form a syntactic constituent; the first would be GF Genitive PT Possessive, and the second, GF Dependent and PT NP.

arguments.definition: A stable bounded area.  It is typically the denotation of the nouns in Locale_by_event, which will be annotated on the target word.  'We need to find a suitable venue for such a large wedding.' 'Tours was the site of the defeat of the Turks by the French.'
Salient parts that make up a Locale.    'We need a meeting site with more computers .'
A place that a Locale is located with respect to.  'The site of their first meeting, west of the Mississippi, has never been disclosed.'
The event for which the locale is known or is named 'The driver died at the scene of the accident.'
The Descriptor is a temporary condition of the Locale.  'The next day, the governor visited the still-smoldering site of the fire.'
The name of the locale. 'The Bonneville site has been a favorite of drivers for many years.'

Presence.definition: An Entity exists at a particular Location, at a particular Time, as observed by an implicit observer. A Depictive and/or Duration phrase is often found.  This frame differs from Existence in that the Location is profiled as a ground where an observer is conceived of as confirming the Entity's existence.  'Liquid water was present on the surface of Mars billions of years ago.'  'Urate was present in varying concentrations in the bathing solution only.'  'No one was present. DNI'  'Your presence is appreciated. DNI'  In some cases, the Location may be recoverable from phrases that primarily express peripheral information:  'Was the senator present for the committee vote?' 'Was the senator present for the committee vote?'

arguments.definition: The Entity whose existence at the Location is confirmed.
The Location of the Entity. The Location is conceived as a ground for an event of inspection to determine the presense of the Entity.
The time when the Entity is present at the Location.
A separate description of the state of the Entity when it is present.

The time period during which the Entity is present. In this frame, Duration may be expressed with for preceding an event which stands for the duration of the event. In cases where the Entity is sentient, there may be an inference that the Entity's intent is to be present so as to participate in the event.  'I can be present for the first half of the ceremony and the last part of the reception, but I'll have to leave in the middle.'  'A catalyst should typically be present for the thermal and/or photochemically induced curing of the coating composition applied onto a suitable substrate.'
The purpose of the Entity.  'Mr. Jones will be present to answer your questions.'
A characterization of the presence or absence of the Entity.  'Because of the mills and their conspicuous absence, hundreds of people were uprooted.'
The degree to which the Entity is present.  'The CDH gene exhibited a complete absence of expression in one cell line.'

Proportional_quantity.definition: The Denoted_quantity is (generally) an imprecise characterization of the quantity of Individuals or a Mass, made with reference to a relatively easily and precisely imaginable Reference_quantity.  'It took about three hours, but we 're done now.' 'But there were barely 300 in the whole district. DNI' 'Put in right around a pinch and a half. DNI ' 'She waited a good second before knocking.' 'She waited a good second before knocking.'

arguments.definition: The quantity denoted by phrases headed by the Target.
A substance that is being quantified.
A collection of entities, either quantifiable physical beings (e.g. toads) or quantifiable units whether physical or not (e.g. dollars).
A property of the Denoted_quantity.
A relatively precise quantity in some oft-used form that is used as the basis for defining the Denoted_quantity.
This frame element selects some gradable attribute and modifies the expected value for it.

Reference_text.definition: In a text, a Source_of_information is given that provides a reader of the text with further Information relevant to the text. In this frame the author and reader are completely deprofiled, with the Source_of_information made salient.  'In Densmore's days it was sometimes made of an old-fashioned man's celluloid collar (cf. Densmore 1943: 116).'  'The 'foaming regions' play the role of 'internal shocks' (cf. Piran's recent publication for a review) of GRB theory.'  'Use my() for local variables whenever you can get away with it (but see perlform for where you can't).'

arguments.definition: The Source_of_information is referred to as a source of information related to the current text.  'The accreting matter forms a disc whose instabilities trigger outbursts (see Lasota 2001 for a review of the instability model).'

The Source_of_information contains Information that the reader is directed to.  'The accreting matter forms a disc whose instabilities trigger outbursts (see Lasota 2001 for a review of the instability model). '

Appointing.definition: A Selector, often an individual in a leadership role, appoints a Official to assume an official Role in an organization (which can be expressed as the Body).  'Press secretaries accredit journalists to the sessions.'

arguments.definition: The Selector is responsible for the appointment of the new official.  Typically, it occurs as the External Argument of verbs.
The Official is a person appointed to a recognized position.

Frequently, the Official is referred to only by his/her role. However, the Role can be expressed separately from the leader, usually as either a secondary predicate or in a PP Complement (headed by as).
This FE indicates the Degree to which an event occurs.
Depictive indicates the state of one of the participants during the action.
This FE is used for the Manner of performing an action.
This FE identifies the Means by which  the Selector accomplishes the designation of the Official.
This FE  is used for indicating the Result of an event.
This frame element describes the situation that brought about the new appointment.
The Function is the purpose the Official will fufill.  'Under the new program, SCC will accredit organizations to assess wood flow from certified forests to workshops or factories.'
When the designation of the official takes place.
Where the appointment takes place.
A group of individuals who are elected or appointed to perform some function, and to which the Official is assigned.

Nuclear_process.definition: An Initial_element is converted into a Final_element via a process of decay, fusion, or fission which changes the number or type of hadrons (protons or neutrons) in the nucleus of the atoms that make up the Element.  '5.5 percent of nucleii decay from tritium to He3 in a year .'

arguments.definition: A substance definable in terms of the kind(s) of atoms that make it up.
The type of Element that results from the process.
The type of Element that begins the process.
The time at which the Element undergoes the transformation.
Any description of the Change event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including secondary effects (quietly, loudly) and general descriptions comparing events (the same way).
The extent to which the Element's substance is converted to the Final_element.
The physical or abstract Circumstances under which the change takes place.
An event or state that causes the change to take place.
The number of times an event occurs per some unit of time.
The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.
The location where the nuclear process occurs.

Scope.definition: An Event is described in terms of the diversity of entities that are affected or considered in the Event. Alternatively a Salient_entity which enables or brings about the Event can be similarly described.  'The U.S. government believes that China has not revealed the full scope of its program.' 'A key question is how U.S. deployment of ballistic missile defense will affect the pace and scope of Chinese strategic modernization.'

arguments.definition: The state-of-affairs that affects a set of entities.
The feature of an Salient_entity which is under discussion.
The entity which enables or causes the Event being judged.

Preliminaries.definition: This frame describes means actions (Preparatory_acts) that are taken by an Agent for the purpose of preparing for a later act.  Contrast this frame with a scenario involving earlier versions of some entity being superseded by later versions (e.g., preliminary results, advance copy).  'This update lays the groundwork for future improvements.'

arguments.definition: The Agent uses the Preparatory_act to acheive a Purpose.

The action performed by the Agent that is a preliminary to the achievement of the Purpose. The Preparatory_act may also be expressed by a result of such an act.  'The company's actions at that stage were simply preliminary to the takeover.' 'Nothing remarkable could be found, as it was almost certainly a preliminary book to the final publication of results.'
The ultimate goal or purpose of the Agent, which the Preparatory_act enables.
A characteristic of the Preparatory_act, Agent, or other participant.
The extent to which the Preparatory_act is distant from the achievement of the Purpose.
The area, field, or domain for which the preliminary action is relevant.  'This laid the political groundwork for his victory in May.'
The time at which the Preparatory_act takes place.
The place where the Preparatory_act takes place.
The part of the larger process that is preliminary to the achievement of the Purpose.  'We are still in the preliminary phases.'

Ineffability.definition: A Stimulus inspires a feeling of awe and interest in a (generally implicit or generic) Experiencer due to desirable qualities which are difficult to explain.  Alternatively, the Attribute of the Stimulus may be described instead.  'There is a certain je-ne-sais-quoi about that city .'

arguments.definition: The entity which inspires a feeling of amazement at its exceptionality.
The Experiencer experiences the emotion brought about by the Stimulus
An expression of how unusual the ineffability of the Stimulus is.
This FE marks expressions that indicate a set of conditions under which the Stimulus is able to bring about the emotion.
The Parameter is the area in which the Stimulus brings about an effect on the Experiencer.
The Comparison_set is the set of individuals the Stimulus is compared to when determining the Degree of the emotional reaction.
A feature of the Stimulus which causes a particular experience.  'That night was magic in every way .'
An expression of the attribute of ineffability.  'She had a magical quality .'

Alternatives.definition: There exist a number of different possible Situations that may happen in the future.  (In some cases, the Situation is concurrent or past, and only the knowledge of which has happened is in the future.)  In most cases, there is an Agent involved who has to consider which of the possible Situations will or should occur.  A Salient_entity which is deeply involved in the Situation may also be mentioned.  'You have but two choices for your daughter .'  While all the members of this frame denote possible situations, in principle, this frame could be split into a number of subtypes on the following basis:  ''1. Future.n, and most uses of alternative.n and possibility.n all evoke nothing more than a simple possible situation (not necessarily an Situation) with no Agent; the remaining frames would inherit from this. ''2. Use.n evokes different possible things that can be done with a Salient_entity (i.e., Purposes) and thus uses the Using frame; in this frame, the target denotes the Purpose that can be achieved. ''3. way.n evokes different events that can lead to an Outcome (not necessarily a Purpose); this frame should use the Means frame.  In this frame, the target denotes the possible Means actions. ''4. option.n, choice.n, and many instances of alternative.n and possibility.n, evoke possible Situations that an implicit or explicit Agent can bring about at will.  A Purpose that would be served by bringing these Situations about may be mentioned. A Salient_entity related to the Purpose may occur in place of the Purpose.

arguments.definition: Something that may happen in the future, or at least whose factual status is unresolved. This is often tagged in a second FE layer and generally contains the target.  'You have a chance at life.'
An individual involved in the Event.  "You have a choice."
The number of different future Events under consideration.  'There are two possibilities.'
An entity intimately involved in the Event.  'You have one choice to make for him.'
The state-of-affairs that the Agent hopes to bring about which is associated with some of the possible Events but not others.  'There 's only one choice to get what you want .'

Have_associated.definition: A Topical_entity has properties which are affected by the existence and association of an Entity.  'By the 1920s a characteristic book had black and white photographic illustrations only .'  'Their schools had an improved and more balanced curriculum .'  'With dual citizenship , Stephen now had two presidents he hated .'

arguments.definition: Some entity, abstract or concrete, which is stated to exist and be associated with the Topical_entity.
The time at which the Entity exists and is associated with the Topical_entity
The period during which the Entity exists in association with the Topical_entity.
A situation, force, or entity which brings about the existence of the Entity or its association with the Topical_entity.
The place where the Entity is associated with the Topical_entity.
Circumstances marks expressions that indicate a set of conditions under which the Entity is declared to exist in association with the Topical_entity.
The perspective of an individual who judges whether they consider the Entity to be associated with the Topical_entity.  'In the United States' eyes, the country doesn't have any real infrastructure.'

This FE signifies that the state of affairs expressed by the main clause (containing the target) occurs or holds, and something other than that state of affairs would be expected given the state of affairs in the concessive clause.
This FE describes a participant of the state of affairs introduced by the target as being in some state during the action.
The entity under discussion, whose states and properties are impacted by its association with the Entity.
The length of time from when the event denoted by the target began to be repeated to when it stopped.

Visit_host.definition: A Visitor matches location with a Host by going to a place strongly associated with a Host, the Host_location (often a place of residence, employment, or government), in order to achieve a Purpose. The Host allows the use of his/her resources. The visit is often social in nature.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that heads toward and is temporarily with the Host in order to fulfil some Purpose.
An individual that allows the use of his or her resources for the benefit of the Visitor.
The activity that is enabled by the hospitality of the Host and that the Visitor wishes to achieve.
The location that the Visitor normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.
The location associated with the Host, where the Visitor arrives at and remains during the visit.

Visiting_scenario.definition: An Agent and an Entity become co-located. The Agent in pursuit of a Purpose, and temporarily remains with the Entity to fulfill this Purpose and then departs again, usually back to their Normal_location.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that heads toward and is temporarily with the Entity in order to fulfil some Purpose.
A place that is permanently associated with entities or characteristics that the Agent wishes to use for some Purpose.
The activity that is enabled by the Entity and that the Agent wishes to achieve.
The location that the Agent normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.

Visitor_and_host.definition: A Visitor and a Host become co-located at a location strongly associated with the Host. The Visitor is allowed by the Host to use the Host's location and/or resources for the achievement of a Purpose. The visit is often social in nature.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that heads toward and is temporarily with the Host in order to fulfil some Purpose.
An individual that allows the use of his or her resources for the benefit of the Visitor.
The activity that is enabled by the Host and that the Visitor wishes to achieve.
The location that the Visitor normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.

A location strongly associated with (in the territory of) the Host, often a place of residence, government, or employment. The Visitor is allowed onto the Host_location and may be invited to make use of it or resources contained within it.

Visiting_scenario_arrival.definition: An Agent arrives at a location that should help them achieve their Purpose. This situation is point-of-view-neutral.

arguments.definition: Agent is the object that moves under its own power.

Normal_location is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion. While Normal_location expressions are possible in this frame, they are relatively infrequent.  If present, they often express a general direction from which a Agent moves, rather than a landmark away from which it moves.
Path is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Normal_location nor a Goal.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a via-sense.

Goal is any expression that tells where the Agent ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.  Although always conceptually present and specific, Goal may sometimes be understood from context, rather than expressed by any separate constituent.

A Manner expression  describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion.  Descriptions of speed, steadiness, grace, means of motion, and other things count as Manner expressions.
This FE identifies the Means by which an Agent arrives.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Agent is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Agent.   Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.
This FE identifies the Time when arriving occurs.
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Agent arrives at the Goal.
The place where the visiting occurs

Visiting_scenario_departing.definition: An Agent departs from the Source, normally bound for their normal location. This is a point-of-view-neutral conception of the departure.

arguments.definition: This is the individual which moves under their own power.
Any constituent that expresses the initial position of the Agent, before the change of location, is tagged with Source. Often the Source is understood from context.
Any description of the trajectory of the departure which is neither a Source nor a Goal expresses the frame element Path.
This FE labels any expression which tells where the Agent ends up, or would end up, as a result of departing from the Source.

Any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion expresses the frame element Manner. Descriptions of steadiness, grace, and many other things count as Manner expressions, though Speed and Means should be tagged using the more specific FE labels. 'The messenger left the room clumsily.'
The action of the Agent which results in their departure.
This frame element labels words or phrases that describe how quickly the Agent is moving.
The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Agent is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Agent. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium.
The distance that the Agent has traveled.
The Time at which the departure takes place.
The Place is the location in  which the departing takes place.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Agent departs from the Source.

Visiting_scenario_stay.definition: An Agent matches location with an Entity in order to fulfill some  Purpose. Quite often, the Purpose is social- or entertainment-oriented. This scene is point-of-view-neutral.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that is temporarily with the Entity in order to fulfil some Purpose.
The physical entity that is permanently associated with entities or characteristics that the Agent wishes to use for some Purpose.  During the visit, the Agent matches location with the Entity.
A state (of the Agent) that results as a consequence of the Agent being situated at the Entity.
The activity that is enabled by the Entity and that the Agent wishes to achieve.
The location that the Agent normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.
The time at which a visit is made.
The amount of time that the Agent spends at the Entity.
Any overall description of the details of the visit, either in terms of how it matches other events (the same way) or in terms of states of the Agent that affect the action.
A description of the position of the Agent during the visit.
An action of the Agent that enables their visit.
The number of instances of the described event.
A characterization of the average number of times a visit happens over a period of time.

Drop_in_on.definition: A Visitor arrives at the Host_location as a guest of the Host, for the purpose of achieving a Purpose. The Purpose is often social in nature, i.e., the visit itself constitutes a goal.  'I'm gonna drop in on Kieth for a while.'

arguments.definition: The Visitor arrives at the Host_location to visit the Host for a Purpose.

Normal_location is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion. While Normal_location expressions are possible in this frame, they are relatively infrequent.  If present, they often express a general direction from which a Visitor moves, rather than a landmark away from which it moves.
Path is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Normal_location nor the Host or Host_location.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a via-sense.

The Host is the person highly associated with the goal location of the Visitor, and who allows the Visitor onto his/her territory, and possibly to make use of available resources. The Host and Visitor and in a host-guest relationship.

A Manner expression  describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion.  Descriptions of speed, steadiness, grace, means of motion, and other things count as Manner expressions.
This FE identifies the Means by which an Visitor arrives.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Visitor is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Visitor.   Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.
This FE identifies the Time when arriving occurs.
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Visitor arrives at a location associated with the Host.
The Host_location is a place primarily associated with the Host.
The Containing_event denotes an event or state of affairs that occurs or holds at a time that includes the time during which the visiting takes place.
The frequency with whic hthe Visitor drops in on a Host.
The length of time that the Visitor remains with the Host.
The larger area within which the visiting takes place.
This FE indicates that the visiting is a particular instance in a series of repeated visiting events.
A state of affairs that explains why the Visitor is making a visit.

Visit_host_arrival.definition: The Visitor arrives at the Host_location to visit the Host.

arguments.definition: The Visitor goes to the Host

Normal_location is any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion. While Normal_location expressions are possible in this frame, they are relatively infrequent.  If present, they often express a general direction from which a Visitor moves, rather than a landmark away from which it moves.
Path is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a Normal_location nor a Host_location.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a via-sense.
The Host welcomes the Visitor as a guest. The location strongly associated with the Host serves as the goal of the Visitor's motion.

A Manner expression  describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion.  Descriptions of speed, steadiness, grace, means of motion, and other things count as Manner expressions.
This FE identifies the Means by which an Visitor arrives.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Visitor is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Visitor.   Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.
This FE identifies the Time when arriving occurs.
This FE identifies the purpose for which the Visitor arrives at the Host or Host_location.
The Host_location is a location associated with the Host, and is commonly the place of residence or employment of the Host.
The place where the arrival event occurs.

Visit_host_stay.definition: A Visitor is located with a Host for a visit.

arguments.definition: The sentient entity that is temporarily with the Host in order to fulfil some Purpose.

The Host welcomes the Visitor to his/her location, with which he/she is permanently associated. The Host allows the Visitor use of resources to accomplish a Purpose.  During the visit, the Visitor matches location with the Host.
A state (of the Visitor) that results as a consequence of the Visitor being situated with the Host.
The activity that is enabled by the Host and that the Visitor wishes to achieve.
The location that the Visitor normally resides in or is (permanently) associated with.
The time at which a visit is made.
The amount of time that the Visitor spends with the Host.
Any overall description of the details of the visit, either in terms of how it matches other events (the same way) or in terms of states of the Visitor that affect the action.
A description of the position of the Visitor during the visit.
An action of the Visitor that enables their visit.
The number of instances of the described event.
A characterization of the average number of times a visit happens over a period of time.
The Host_location is the location permanently associated with the Host, and which the Visitor stays at temporarily for the acheiving of some Purpose.

Visit_host_departure.definition: A Visitor departs from a Host_location after having visited a Host.

arguments.definition: The Visitor departs from the location of the Host.
The Visitor departs from the Host_location, a location strongly associated with the Host.
Any description of the trajectory of the departure which is neither a Source nor a Goal expresses the frame element Path.  In this frame, Path expressions almost always have a sense meaning 'via'.
This FE labels any expression which tells where the Visitor ends up, or would end up, as a result of departing from the Source.

Any expression which describes a property of motion which is not directly related to the trajectory of motion expresses the frame element Manner. Descriptions of steadiness, grace, and many other things count as Manner expressions, though Speed and Means should be tagged using the more specific FE labels.
The action of the Visitor which results in their departure.
This frame element labels words or phrases that describe how quickly the Visitor is moving.

The Mode_of_transportation expresses how the motion of the Visitor is effected, by its body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the Visitor. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium.   In this frame, Mode_of_transportation is often expressed obliquely in a prepositional phrase headed by 'in' or 'by'.
The distance that the Visitor has traveled.
The Time at which the departure takes place.
>The Place is the location in  which the departing takes place.
This FE identifies the Purpose for which the Visitor departs from the Source.
The Host allows the Visitor to use his/her resources, and to remain temporarily at the Host_location.

Receive_visitor_scenario.definition: A (potential) Visitor arrives at a location associated with a (potential) Host. The Host permits the Visitor to enter the location, and allows the Visitor to avail him/herself of available resources, in order to pursue some goal. The visit is often for social or entertainment reasons. After a temporary stay at the Host's location, the Visitor departs.

arguments.definition: The Host allows the Visitor to remain with him/her to acheive a goal.
The Visitor temporarily remains with the Host in order to achieve his/her purpose.
The goal of the Host in allowing the Visitor to enter the Host's location.

Have_visitor_over.definition: A Host, at a location strongly associated with him/herself (such as a place of employment or residence), temporarily hosts a Visitor so that the Visitor can achieve a goal. The purpose of the visit is often social in nature.  'We had him over for tea.'

arguments.definition: The Host allows the Visitor to enter his/her location (house, office, etc.) for a temporary period so that the Visitor can achieve a goal. The goal is often socially-motivated (e.g., socialization between the Visitor and the Host).
The Visitor is a guest of the Host at a location strongly associated with the Host.
The Purpose of the Host in hosting the Visitor.

Version_sequence.definition: An entity goes through several versions, from initial to final.  'This is my first draft.'

arguments.definition: The Item is one version among several versions (which may or may not yet exist), progressively getting closer to a final version.
The degree of the distance the Item is from the final version.  'I warn you, this is a very rough draft.'

Hospitality.definition: A Host is judged regarding their attitude as a potential host in a guest-host relationship. The Host exhibits a Behavior that is judged as demonstrating a particular degree hospitality towards a Guest. Alternatively, the Host may reveal an Expressor that indicates a particular sort of attitude.  'I found the board to be very hospitable to Russian graduates.'

arguments.definition: The Host is the person whose Behavior towards others as a (potential) host is evaluated.
The Guest is the entity which is positively or negatively treated by the Host.
The Behavior is the action of the Host on which the evaluation of the Host's character is based.
The Degree is the extent to which the Host exhibits the particular Behavior towards others.
The Topic is the situation or person that the Host's Behavior responds to or is related to.
The Expressor is the body part or action by a body part which indicates the character of the Host.
The Manner is the way in which the Host embodies the characters of a good or poor host.
The individual whose point of view is taken in assigning the evaluation.

Supporting.definition: A Supporter assists to strengthen the Supported by lending itself in material aid (or abstract assistance in the case of metaphorical uses).   'The bottom of the wall is supported by the foundation.'  'Many legislators have supported the industry in the past.'  'The revetment layers buttressed the mud-mortared cobblestone core wall.'  'Online gambling can bolster the US economy.'

arguments.definition: The Supporter acts to benefit the Supported by providing additional strength or stability.
The Supported is given strength through the assistance of the Supporter.
The measure to which the Supporter's assistance brings the Supported added strength and support.  'The physical therapist must totally support tthe patient during the exercises.'
The time period during which the Supporter supports the Supported.  'For some seventy years, this judicial fabrication buttressed racial segregation.'

An entity used by the Supporter in service of the Supported's strength by support.  'The troops used their shoulders to support the doors of the keep, as the enemy forces tried to break through.'  'For years, patrons of the organization have supported our bi-weekly tea-times with their generous donations.'
This FE identifies the Manner in which a Supporter supports the Supported.   'The British Government happily buttressed Saddam's appalling oppression of his people'.
An action that the Supporter undertakes in service of the Supported's strengthening.  'The foundation supports the building by distributing the load to the ground below.'
This FE identifies the Place where the support occurs.  'In England, economic incentives are buttressed by closing certain overdoctored areas from new practices.'
This FE identifies when the support occurs.  'Early in the twentieth century, such economic arguments buttressed the creation of a National Park Service.'
The situation that the Supporter wishes to bring about by supporting the Supported.   'The porch tower of Saint-Germain-des-Prs is sturdily buttressed to support the weight of its massive bells'.
A state-of-affairs from which the accomplishment would be predicted.
A clause describing the event as a whole.

Degree.definition: LUs in this frame modify a gradable attribute and describe intensities at the extreme positions on a scale.  'She is very brave.'  'It is that simple!'  'The feuds are so vicious because the stakes are so low.'  'The plant is totally red  without the slightest hint of green.'

Medium.definition: Words in this frame describe a relationship in which an Item is expressed through a Text. 'The act of murder is rampant in the Bible.'  'In his State of the Union Address, President Bush committed our nation to achieving three great goals of our time.'  'Linnaeus in his writings often quotes his great predecessor.'

arguments.definition: The written source, body of work, or linguistic utterance in which the Item is found/expressed.
The piece of information or expression that is contained within the Text.
How often the Item appears in the Text.   'Everyday in the newspaper there are articles relating to science and technology.'
When the Item appears in the Text.

Hunting.definition: A Hunter tries to gain Food by way of outsmarting or tracking a living. The Hunter hopes the attempt will result in the catching and killing of the living entity that is intended for human consumption. The act of seeking Food inherently involves the assistance of some tool, which can be an extension of the Hunter's body or an artifact fashioned or exploited for the use of food seeking, catching, and/or killing.  'In the Congo, he hunted big game for the first time.'  'People still fish bass in the lake.'  'Folks from Northern California hunt brilliantly. INI '

arguments.definition: The Hunter is the agent hoping to obtain Food.
Food is the sought-out item by the Hunter.

The Instrument is used by the Hunter as a tool to help obtain Food. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)  'Late Prehistoric peoples hunted with the bow and arrow.'
For what length of time the Hunter attempted to obtain Food.   'We all fished for several hours.'
The Manner in which the Hunter makes the attempt for Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which an attempt at achieving a Food obtainment.
The failure or success of an attempt.  'She successfully hunted and ate a porcupine.'
The greater geographic location where the Hunter attempts to obtain Food.  'Europe's billionaires hunt boars in Romania.'
When the Time seeking action occurs.
An action that the Hunter intends to accomplish by seeking Food.
How often the Hunter attempts to obtain Food.
This FE identifies the amount of effort the Hunter puts into his attempt to obtain Food.
This is the entity to which the Hunter pays attention. It is referred to as Ground because it serves as the background or context for the Food.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.

Co_participant is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the same event as the primary protagonist, regardless of whether the protagonist, and hence the Co-participant, is more agent- or more undergoer-like.

Attempt_obtain_food_scenario.definition: A Seeker is trying to obtain Food and is seeking it within the context of a Ground.

arguments.definition: The Seeker is the agent hoping to obtain Food.
Food is the sought-out item by the Seeker.
The Instrument is used by the Seeker as a tool to help obtain Food. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)
For what length of time the Seeker attempted to obtain Food.
The Manner in which the Seeker makes the attempt for Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which an attempt at achieving a Food obtainment.
The failure or success of an attempt.
The greater geographic location where the Seeker attempts to obtain Food.
When the Food seeking action occurs.
An action that the Seeker intends to accomplish by seeking Food.
How often the Seeker attempts to obtain Food.
This FE identifies the amount of effort the Seeker puts into an attempt to obtain Food.
This is the entity to which the Seeker pays attention. It is referred to as Ground because it serves as the background or context for the Food.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.

Food_gathering.definition: A Gatherer removes Crop ripe and ready to an accepted degree. The Crop comes from a  Source where it has been grown and matured.  'They harvest their pumpkins in the Autumn. INI '  'We bring in the tobacco from the fields during the summer.'  'The stage at which the peppercorns are harvested from the vine decides their colour . CNI'

arguments.definition: The Gatherer is the agent gathering the Crop.  'Small growers can harvest quality crops.'
Crop is item being collected together by the Gatherer.  'Tubers harvested immediately after spraying developed gangrene.'
For what length of time the Gatherer was gathering the Crop.
The Manner in which the Gatherer gathers the Crop.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Crop is gathered.
The greater geographic location where the Gatherer gathers his Crop.
When the Crop gathering action occurs.
An action that the Gatherer intends to accomplish by gathering his Crop.
How often the Gatherer collects his Crop.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
The Source is the ground where the Crop is gathered from.  'They picked the apples from the tallest trees.'
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
This FE describes the amount of effort put into the food gathering event.
The person on who's behalf the Gatherer gathers the Crop.

Hunting_scenario.definition: A Hunter endeavors to- and either fails or succeeds at finding and obtaining Food. This scenario occurs within the context of some Ground within which the preparation, hunt, and success or failure of it plays out.

arguments.definition: The Hunter is the agent hoping to obtain Food.
Food is the sought-out item by the Hunter.
The Instrument is used by the Hunter as a tool to help obtain Food. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)
For what length of time the Hunter attempted to obtain Food.
The Manner in which the Hunter makes the attempt for Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which an attempt at achieving a Food obtainment.
The failure or success of an attempt.
The greater geographic location where the Hunter attempts to obtain Food.
When the Food seeking action occurs.
An action that the Hunter intends to accomplish by seeking Food.
How often the Hunter attempts to obtain Food.
This FE identifies the amount of effort the Hunter puts into an attempt to obtain Food.
This is the entity to which the Hunter pays attention. It is referred to as Ground because it serves as the background or context for the Food.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.

Hunting_success_or_failure.definition: A Hunter succeeds or fails at capturing his sought-out or tracked Food.  'We bagged six roosters.'  'Bottom trawlers catch fish that live on or near the seafloor.'

arguments.definition: The Hunter is the agent that has successfully obtained Food.
Food is the item obtained by the Hunter.
The Instrument is used by the Hunter as a tool to obtain Food.   'He could easily catch fish with his hands.'
The Manner in which the Hunter obtains the Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Food is obtained.
The greater geographic location where the Hunter obtains Food.
When the Food seeking action occurs.
An action that the Hunter intends to accomplish obtaining Food.
How often the Hunter obtains Food.
This FE identifies the amount of effort the Hunter puts into an attempt to obtain Food.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.

Agriculture.definition: In this frame an Agriculturist cultivates Food.  The location or Ground where the Food is cultivated by the Agriculturist is often expressed.  '' 'Peasants were encouraged to cultivate basic food crops such as beans and corn'.  'Shrimp farming seems to be a recipe for disaster'  'Some fields were probably cultivated only in the dry season CNI'

arguments.definition: The Agriculturist is the agent cultivating Food.
Food is the item cultivated by the Agriculturist.  'They cultivate fungi.'
The Instrument is used by the Agriculturist as a tool to help obtain Food. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)
For what length of time the Agriculturist attempted to obtain Food.
The Manner in which the Agriculturist cultivates Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Agriculturist cultivates Food.
The failure or success of an attempt.
The greater geographic location where the Agriculturist cultivates Food.
When the agricultural event occurs.
An action that the Agriculturist intends to accomplish by cultivating Food.
How often the Agriculturist cultivates Food.
This frame element selects some gradable attribute and modifies the expected value for it.  'Most of lowland Britain is intensively cultivated.'
This is the the background or context for the Food to which the Agriculturist pays attention in his agricultural efforts.  'Romans were cultivating the land in Northern Gaul.'
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
This FE indicates the subtype of agriculture that the Agriculturist is engaging in.
This FE appraises the event.
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the agricultural event itself and any of its participants.

Growing_food.definition: A Grower endeavors to tend to and influence the environment of Food so as to foster its growth.  'I grow my own vegetables.'

arguments.definition: The Grower is the agent growing Food.

Food is the item grown by the Grower, which can include things not traditionally eaten, like flowers, etc., or items for other consumption-related uses, like medicines, smokables, etc.   'He grew flowers and potatoes.'

The Instrument is used by the Grower as a tool grow Food. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)  'Heavy-yielding crops are grown with chemical fertilizers'
For what length of time the Grower is growing Food.
The Manner in which the Grower grows Food.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Grower grows Food.
The greater geographic location where the Grower grows Food.
When the growing event occurs.
An action that the Grower intends to accomplish by growing Food.  'He can grow flowers to beautify the garden'
How often the Grower grows Food.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
This is the the physical background or context for the Food to which the Grower pays attention in his growing efforts.
Circumstances describe the state of the world (at a particular time and place) which is specifically independent of the event itself and any of its participants.
The starting state of the Food, e.g., a seed.

Planting.definition: This frame describes a situation in which the Agent puts the Theme into the Ground for the purpose of growing. 'He recently planted some old apple trees. INI '

arguments.definition: The Agent plants the Theme.
Theme is the item planted by the Agent.
The Instrument is used by the Agent as a tool to help obtain the Theme. (This tool is not limited to typical artifacts and can be hands, arms, and other atypical hunting and fishing instruments.)
For what length of time the Agent plants the Theme.
The Manner in which the Agent plants the Theme.
This FE identifies the Means by which the Agent plants the Theme.
The failure or success of an attempt.
The greater geographic location where the Agent plants the Theme.
When the planting event occurs.
An action that the Agent intends to accomplish by planting the Theme.
How often the Agent cultivates the Theme.
This frame element selects some gradable attribute and modifies the expected value for it.
The Ground is the background or context to which the Agent pays attention in his agricultural efforts.
Expressions marked with this extra-thematic FE modify a non-iterative use of the target, and indicate that it is conceived as embedded within an iterated series of similar events or states.
The Depictive describes a participant in the Planting action.
The Co-participant is an entity that participates in the planting event in a coordinated way with another participant.
The Explanation denotes a proposition from which the planting event logically follows.

Image_schema.definition: A Profiled_region is picked out relative to a Ground.

arguments.definition: A region of space located relative to a Ground.
An entity whose location is relatively well-known and which, thus, can serve as a land-mark to identify the Profiled_region.

Proximity_image_schema.definition: A Profiled_region is picked out which is near to (or far from) the Ground to a certain Degree.  The Profiled_region cannot contact or overlap the location of the Ground, as this is categorically different--see Contact_image_schema and Collocation_image_schema.

arguments.definition: A region of space located relative to a Ground that is maximally relevant near the Ground, with decreasing applicability away from the Ground.
An entity whose location is relatively well-known and which, thus, can serve as a land-mark to identify the Profiled_region.
The amount of deviation from an idealized expected distance of the Profiled_region from the Ground.
A region of space located relative to a Ground that is not relevant near the Ground, with increasing applicability away from the Ground.

Collocation_image_schema.definition: A Profiled_region is specified as entirely or largely coinciding with that of a Ground.

arguments.definition: A region of space located at a Ground.
An entity whose location is relatively well-known and which, thus, can serve as a land-mark to identify the Profiled_region.

Bounded_region.definition: An Exterior, Surface, Boundary, and Interior are picked out relative to the Ground.  This Ground may either occupy only the Boundary (in which case the Interior is negative space) or the Ground may fill the Interior.

arguments.definition: A region of space located inside a Ground.
An entity whose location is relatively well-known and which, thus, can serve as a land-mark to identify the Interior, Surface, Boundary, or Exterior regions.
The region located outside of, but in contact with, the Ground.
The region associated with the boundary of the Ground.
The region which is not located inside or in contact with the Ground.

Alignment_image_schema.definition: An Alignment_match region has the same orientation as the relatively linear Ground.  The Alignment_mismatch region is oriented perpendicularly to the Ground.

arguments.definition: A region of space oriented the same as the Ground.
An entity whose location and orientation is relatively well-known and which, thus, can serve as a land-mark to identify the Alignment_match and Alignment_mismatch regions.
A region oriented approximately perpendicular to the Ground

Conquering.definition: This frame describes a Theme losing its autonomy and perhaps sustaining material damage as the result of a successful invasion on the behalf of a Conqueror.  'The Spaniards conquered the Incas with both the Cross and the arquebus'  'He said that the aim had been the takeover of the Soviet government by "advocates of swift privatization"'  'The Romans fell to the Goths in 410 AD.'  'Bright Star campaign forces captured the garrison town of Kajo Kaji'

arguments.definition: The Conqueror is the entity that overtakes the Theme.  'The Achaemenid monarch Cambyses conquered Egypt in the year 525 BC'
The Theme is the land, government, and its people that is seized by the Conqueror.  'Britain had an opportunity to conquer Europe.'
This FE describes the intensity and extent of the conquering event.  'Britain had been ` completely conquered and immediately thrown away ''
The manner in which the Conqueror takes over the Theme.  'He violently captured the castles of La Haye , Preuilly and Champigny'
The action by which the conquering event is made possible through the efforts of the Conqueror.  'They captured the haunted castle by bombarding it with low-energy x-rays.'
The location where the Conqueror takes over the Theme.  'On Planet Earth, humans prefer to conquer those lands whose acquistion offers some economic benefit or advantage.'
